<main id="mainContent" tabindex="-1" role="main">
<section class="uwhr-hero uwhr-hero-image hero-image-height center-v" style="background-image: url(https://hr.uw.edu/dso/wp-content/uploads/sites/6/2023/10/dso-banner.jpg);">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="container">
            <h2 class="hero-title">Disability Services Office</h2>
        </div>
    </div>
</section>

<section class="uwhr-body container">
    <div class="row">

        <nav class="uwhr-breadcrumbs" role="navigation" aria-label="Breadcrumbs"><ol class="breadcrumb"><li class="breadcrumb-item"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/" title="University of Washington Human Resources"><i class="fa fa-lg fa-home"></i></a></li><li class="breadcrumb-item"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/" title="Disability Services Office">Disability Services Office</a></li><li class="breadcrumb-item active">Disability accommodation</li></ol></nav>
        <article class="uwhr-content col-lg-6 push-lg-3">

            <h3 class="title">Disability accommodation</h3><div class="uwhr-child-pages"><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/services-for-faculty-and-staff/">Disability accommodation for employees<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>The University's disability accommodation process is designed to explore reasonable accommodations for employees with medical conditions or disabilities.</p></div><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/managersrole/">Disability accommodation process: manager’s role<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>It's essential for managers to be familiar with the University's disability accommodation policy and know how to respond when an employee brings a concern to your attention.</p></div><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/uw-job-applicants/">Disability accommodation for UW job applicants<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>Contact DSO regarding requests for disability accommodation in the employment application process.</p></div><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/matriculated-students/">Disability accommodation for matriculated students<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>Matriculated students can receive accommodation support from the Disability Resources for Students office.</p></div><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/services-for-students/">Disability services for non-matriculated students<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>DSO provides accommodation, referral information, and assistance for nonmatriculated students with a documented physical, mental, or sensory disability. </p></div><div class="uwhr-child-page"><h4 class="h6 m-b-0 m-t-0"><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/services/services-for-the-public/">Disability accommodation for members of the public<i class="fa fa-angle-right m-l-xs"></i></a></h4><p>Explore the services and accommodations UW provides to those visiting the campus. </p></div><div>

        </div></div></article>

        
<aside class="uwhr-sidebar" role="complementary">
	<div id="text-2" class="widget widget_text"><h4>Contact</h4>			<div class="textwidget"><p><strong><a href="https://hr.uw.edu/dso/contacts/">Disability Services Office</a></strong><br>
206-543-6450<br>
206-543-6452 (TTY)<br>
VP: 253-642-0142<br>
<a href="mailto:dso@uw.edu">dso@uw.edu</a></p>
</div>
		</div>	</aside>

			</ul></li>

					</nav>
					<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading mw-first-heading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">India</span></h1>
							
<div id="p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown mw-portlet mw-portlet-lang">
	<input type="checkbox" id="p-lang-btn-checkbox" role="button" aria-haspopup="true" data-event-name="ui.dropdown-p-lang-btn" class="vector-dropdown-checkbox mw-interlanguage-selector" aria-label="Go to an article in another language. Available in 295 languages">
	<label id="p-lang-btn-label" for="p-lang-btn-checkbox" class="vector-dropdown-label cdx-button cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--weight-quiet cdx-button--action-progressive mw-portlet-lang-heading-295" aria-hidden="true"><span class="vector-icon mw-ui-icon-language-progressive mw-ui-icon-wikimedia-language-progressive"></span>

	</div>

					<div id="contentSub"><div id="mw-content-subtitle"></div></div>
					
					
					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the Republic of India. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/India_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="India (disambiguation)">India (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

<ul class="mw-collapsible-content" style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit; list-style: none; margin-left: 0;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0">8th Scheduled <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1129693374"><div class="hlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Assamese_language" title="Assamese language">Assamese</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Boro_language_(India)" title="Boro language (India)">Boro</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Dogri_language" title="Dogri language">Dogri</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Kannada" title="Kannada">Kannada</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_language" title="Kashmiri language">Kashmiri</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Konkani_language" title="Konkani language">Konkani</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Maithili_language" title="Maithili language">Maithili</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Malayalam" title="Malayalam">Malayalam</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Meitei_language" title="Meitei language">Manipuri</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Nepali_language" title="Nepali language">Nepali</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Odia_language" title="Odia language">Odia</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Santali_language" title="Santali language">Santali</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Telugu_language" title="Telugu language">Telugu</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a></li></ul></div></li><li style="line-height: inherit; class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.in" title=".in">.in</a> (<a href="/wiki/.in#Internationalised_domain_names_and_country_codes" title=".in">others</a>)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>India</b>, officially the <b>Republic of India</b> (<a href="/wiki/ISO_15919" title="ISO 15919">ISO</a>: <span title="ISO 15919 Indic (Hindi language) transliteration"><i lang="hi-Latn">Bhārat Gaṇarājya</i></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[22]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>.  It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">seventh-largest country by area</a>; the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_(United_Nations)" title="List of countries by population (United Nations)">most populous country</a> as of June 2023;<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[24]</a></sup> and from the time of its independence in 1947, the world's most populous democracy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2012327_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2012327-34">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-stein-arnold_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stein-arnold-35">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisher2018184–185_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher2018184–185-36">[27]</a></sup> Bounded by the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Ocean" title="Indian Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> on the south, the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a> on the southwest, and the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a> on the southeast, it shares land borders with <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to the west;<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[j]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a> to the north; and <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[k]</a></sup> to the east. In the Indian Ocean, India is in the vicinity of <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Maldives" title="Maldives">Maldives</a>; its <a href="/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands" title="Andaman and Nicobar Islands">Andaman and Nicobar Islands</a> share a maritime border with <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, Myanmar, and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Modern_humans" class="mw-redirect" title="Modern humans">Modern humans</a> arrived on the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> from Africa no later than 55,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-39">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018p1_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018p1-40">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018p23_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018p23-41">[30]</a></sup>
Their long occupation, initially in varying forms of isolation as hunter-gatherers, has made the region highly diverse, second only to Africa in human <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">genetic diversity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-28a_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-42">[31]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Settled life</a> emerged on the subcontinent in the western margins of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus</a> <a href="/wiki/River_basin" class="mw-redirect" title="River basin">river basin</a> 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a> of the third millennium <a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">BCE</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-2_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-2-43">[32]</a></sup>
By 1200&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span>, an <a href="/wiki/Proto-language" title="Proto-language">archaic form</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a>, had <a href="/wiki/Trans-cultural_diffusion" class="mw-redirect" title="Trans-cultural diffusion">diffused</a> into India from the northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-Lowe2015_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lowe2015-44">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Combined-4-Rigveda_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-4-Rigveda-45">[34]</a></sup> Its evidence today is found in the hymns of the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>. Preserved by an <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">oral tradition</a> that was <a href="/wiki/Indian_mathematics#Styles_of_memorisation" title="Indian mathematics">resolutely vigilant</a>, the <i>Rigveda</i> records the dawning of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> in India.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-3_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-3-46">[35]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_languages" title="Dravidian languages">Dravidian languages</a> of India were supplanted in the northern and western regions.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-4_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-4-47">[36]</a></sup>
By 400&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span>, <a href="/wiki/Social_stratification" title="Social stratification">stratification</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_exclusion" title="Social exclusion">exclusion</a> by <a href="/wiki/Caste" title="Caste">caste</a> had emerged within Hinduism,<sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-16a_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-16a-48">[37]</a></sup>
and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="History of Buddhism in India">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jainism" title="History of Jainism">Jainism</a> had arisen, proclaiming <a href="/wiki/Social_order" title="Social order">social orders</a> unlinked to heredity.<sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-59_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-59-49">[38]</a></sup>
Early political consolidations gave rise to the loose-knit <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empires</a> based in the <a href="/wiki/Ganges_Basin" title="Ganges Basin">Ganges Basin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-5_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-5-50">[39]</a></sup>
Their collective <a href="/wiki/Era" title="Era">era</a> was suffused with wide-ranging creativity,<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-6_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-6-51">[40]</a></sup> but also marked by the declining status of women,<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-7_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-7-52">[41]</a></sup> and the incorporation of <a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchability</a> into an organised system of belief.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[l]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493-53">[42]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Middle_kingdoms_of_India#The_Deccan_plateau_and_South" title="Middle kingdoms of India">Middle kingdoms</a> exported Dravidian-languages scripts and religious cultures to the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AsherAsher2006-17_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-17-55">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early medieval era, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a> became established on India's southern and western coasts.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-8_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-8-56">[44]</a></sup>
Muslim armies from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> intermittently overran India's northern plains,<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-13_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-13-57">[45]</a></sup>
eventually founding the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a>, and drawing northern India into the cosmopolitan <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">networks of medieval Islam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-10_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-10-58">[46]</a></sup>
In the 15th century, the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a> created a long-lasting composite Hindu culture in south India.<sup id="cite_ref-AsherAsher2006-74_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-74-59">[47]</a></sup>
In the <a href="/wiki/Punjab" title="Punjab">Punjab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> emerged, rejecting institutionalised religion.<sup id="cite_ref-AsherAsher2006-267_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-267-60">[48]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, in 1526, ushered in two centuries of relative peace,<sup id="cite_ref-AsherAsher2006-152_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-152-61">[49]</a></sup>
leaving a legacy of luminous architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[m]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-106_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-106-62">[50]</a></sup>
Gradually expanding <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">rule of the British East India Company</a> followed, turning India into a colonial economy, but also consolidating its <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-11_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-11-64">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Crown rule</a> began in 1858. The rights promised to Indians were granted slowly,<sup id="cite_ref-Combined-12_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Combined-12-65">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPeers2013[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddyQuAgAAQBAJpgPA76_76]_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeers2013[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddyQuAgAAQBAJpgPA76_76]-66">[53]</a></sup> but <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">technological changes</a> were introduced, and modern ideas of education and the public life took root.<sup id="cite_ref-EmbreeHay1988_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EmbreeHay1988-67">[54]</a></sup> A pioneering and influential nationalist movement emerged, which was noted for nonviolent resistance and became the major factor in ending British rule.<sup id="cite_ref-Marshall2001_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marshall2001-68">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Chiriyankandath2016_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chiriyankandath2016-69">[56]</a></sup> In 1947 the British Indian Empire was <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partitioned</a> into two independent <a href="/wiki/Dominion#India,_Pakistan_and_Bangladesh" title="Dominion">dominions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-fisher-partition_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fisher-partition-70">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-chatterji-partition_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chatterji-partition-71">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-talbot-sing_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-talbot-sing-72">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-khan-great-partition_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-khan-great-partition-73">[60]</a></sup> a Hindu-majority <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_India" title="Dominion of India">Dominion of India</a> and a Muslim-majority <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan" title="Dominion of Pakistan">Dominion of Pakistan</a>, amid large-scale loss of life and an unprecedented migration.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>India has been a <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal republic</a> since 1950, governed through a democratic <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>. It is a <a href="/wiki/Pluralism_(political_philosophy)" title="Pluralism (political philosophy)">pluralistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multilingualism" title="Multilingualism">multilingual</a> and <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multi-ethnic society</a>. India's population grew from 361 million in 1951 to almost 1.4&nbsp;billion in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-219_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-219-75">[62]</a></sup>
During the same time, its nominal <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a> increased from US$64 annually to US$2,601, and its literacy rate from 16.6% to 74%. From being a comparatively destitute country in 1951,<sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-8_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-8-76">[63]</a></sup> India has become a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fast-growing</a> <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">major economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Information_technology_in_India" title="Information technology in India">a hub for information technology services</a>, with an expanding middle class.<sup id="cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265-77">[64]</a></sup> India has <a href="/wiki/ISRO" title="ISRO">a space programme</a> with several planned or completed <a href="/wiki/List_of_Solar_System_probes" title="List of Solar System probes">extraterrestrial missions</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Indian movies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_India" title="Music of India">music</a>, and spiritual teachings play an increasing role in global culture.<sup id="cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2012-266_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-266-78">[65]</a></sup> India has substantially reduced <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_India" title="Poverty in India">its rate of poverty</a>, though at the cost of increasing economic inequality.<sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018-216-a_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018-216-a-79">[66]</a></sup> India is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear-weapon state</a>, which <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military expenditures">ranks high in military expenditure</a>. It has disputes over <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> with its neighbours, Pakistan and China, unresolved since the mid-20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-kashmir-disputes_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kashmir-disputes-80">[67]</a></sup> Among the socio-economic challenges India faces are <a href="/wiki/Gender_inequality_in_India" title="Gender inequality in India">gender inequality</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition_in_India" title="Malnutrition in India">child malnutrition</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-NarayanJohn2018-lead_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NarayanJohn2018-lead-81">[68]</a></sup> and rising levels of <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_India" title="Air pollution in India">air pollution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BalakrishnanDey2019-lead_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BalakrishnanDey2019-lead-82">[69]</a></sup> India's land is <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Megadiverse country">megadiverse</a>, with four <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspots" class="mw-redirect" title="Biodiversity hotspots">biodiversity hotspots</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN-India_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-India-83">[70]</a></sup> Its forest cover comprises 21.7% of its area.<sup id="cite_ref-ISFR_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISFR-84">[71]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_India" title="Wildlife of India">India's wildlife</a>, which has traditionally been viewed with tolerance in <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">India's culture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaranthGopal2005374_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranthGopal2005374-85">[72]</a></sup> is supported among these forests, and elsewhere, in <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_India" title="Protected areas of India">protected habitats</a>.
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_for_India" title="Names for India">Names for India</a></div>
<p>According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> (third edition 2009), the name "India" is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">Classical Latin</a> <i>India</i>, a reference to <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a> and an uncertain region to its east. In turn the name "India" derived successively from <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Greek" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic Greek">Hellenistic Greek</a> <i>India</i> (<i> Ἰνδία</i>), <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">ancient Greek</a> <i>Indos</i> (<i> Ἰνδός</i>), <a href="/wiki/Old_Persian" title="Old Persian">Old Persian</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Hindush" title="Hindush">Hindush</a></i> (an eastern province of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>), and ultimately its <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">cognate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> <i>Sindhu</i>, or "river", specifically the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> and, by implication, its well-settled southern basin.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThieme1970447–450_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThieme1970447–450-87">[74]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greeks</a> referred to the Indians as <i>Indoi</i> (<i><span class="plainlinks"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/langcodes_name.php?code_ID=">Ἰνδοί</a></span></i>), which translates as "The people of the Indus".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuiper201086_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper201086-88">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i><a href="/wiki/Names_for_India#Bhārata" title="Names for India">Bharat</a></i> (<span title="ISO 15919 Indic (Hindi language) transliteration"><i lang="hi-Latn">Bhārat</i></span>; <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">pronounced</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="hns-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu" title="Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu">[ˈbʱaːɾət]</a></span> <span class="ext-phonos"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-1" class="ext-phonos-PhonosButton noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/7\/79\/Hi-Bharat.ogg\/Hi-Bharat.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;Hi-Bharat.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/79/Hi-Bharat.ogg/Hi-Bharat.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Hi-Bharat.ogg" title="File:Hi-Bharat.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup></span>), mentioned in both <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">Indian epic poetry</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">Constitution of India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014-89">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[77]</a></sup> is used in its variations by <a href="/wiki/Names_of_India_in_its_official_languages" title="Names of India in its official languages">many Indian languages</a>. A modern rendering of the historical name <i>Bharatavarsha</i>, which applied originally to <a href="/wiki/North_India" title="North India">North India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2014_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2014-91">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddYM4DwAAQBAJpgPA253_253]_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddYM4DwAAQBAJpgPA253_253]-92">[79]</a></sup> <i>Bharat</i> gained increased currency from the mid-19th century as a native name for India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014-89">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003-93">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Hindustan" title="Hindustan">Hindustan</a></i> (<span class="IPA nowrap" lang="hns-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu" title="Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu">[ɦɪndʊˈstaːn]</a></span> <span class="ext-phonos"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-2" class="ext-phonos-PhonosButton noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" data-ooui="{&quot;_&quot;:&quot;mw.Phonos.PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;href&quot;:&quot;\/\/upload.wikimedia.org\/wikipedia\/commons\/transcoded\/4\/46\/Hindustan.ogg\/Hindustan.ogg.mp3&quot;,&quot;rel&quot;:[&quot;nofollow&quot;],&quot;framed&quot;:false,&quot;icon&quot;:&quot;volumeUp&quot;,&quot;data&quot;:{&quot;ipa&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;text&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;lang&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,&quot;wikibase&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;file&quot;:&quot;Hindustan.ogg&quot;},&quot;classes&quot;:[&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton&quot;,&quot;noexcerpt&quot;,&quot;ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel&quot;]}"><a role="button" tabindex="0" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/46/Hindustan.ogg/Hindustan.ogg.mp3" rel="nofollow" aria-label="Play audio" title="Play audio" class="oo-ui-buttonElement-button"><span class="oo-ui-iconElement-icon oo-ui-icon-volumeUp"></span><span class="oo-ui-labelElement-label"></span><span class="oo-ui-indicatorElement-indicator oo-ui-indicatorElement-noIndicator"></span></a></span><sup class="ext-phonos-attribution noexcerpt navigation-not-searchable"><a href="/wiki/File:Hindustan.ogg" title="File:Hindustan.ogg">ⓘ</a></sup></span>) is a <a href="/wiki/Middle_Persian" title="Middle Persian">Middle Persian</a> name for India that became popular by the 13th century,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[81]</a></sup> and was used widely since the era of the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>. The meaning of <i>Hindustan</i> has varied, referring to a region encompassing present-day northern India and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> or to India in its near entirety.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014_89-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClémentin-Ojha2014-89">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003-93">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[82]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_India" title="History of India">History of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Republic of India">History of the Republic of India</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_India">Ancient India</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Battle_at_Lanka,_Ramayana,_Udaipur,_1649-53.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg/220px-Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="129" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg/330px-Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg/440px-Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5100" data-file-height="2995"></a><figcaption>Manuscript illustration, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1650</span>, of the Sanskrit epic <a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a>, composed in story-telling fashion <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 400&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span><sup id="cite_ref-Lowe2017-epic_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lowe2017-epic-96">[83]</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>About 55,000 years ago, the first modern humans, or <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" class="mw-redirect" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i>, had arrived on the Indian subcontinent from Africa, where they had earlier evolved.<sup id="cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-39">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dyson2018p1_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyson2018p1-40">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018p23_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018p23-41">[30]</a></sup> The earliest known modern human remains in South Asia date to about 30,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-39">[28]</a></sup> After 6500&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span>, evidence for domestication of food crops and animals, construction of permanent structures, and storage of agricultural surplus appeared in <a href="/wiki/Mehrgarh" title="Mehrgarh">Mehrgarh</a> and other sites in <a href="/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan" title="Balochistan, Pakistan">Balochistan, Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105-97">[84]</a></sup> These gradually developed into the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200421–23_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200421–23-98">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105_97-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105-97">[84]</a></sup> the first urban culture in South Asia,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009181_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009181-99">[86]</a></sup> which flourished during 2500–1900&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span> in Pakistan and western India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPossehl20032_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl20032-100">[87]</a></sup> Centred around cities such as <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harappa" title="Harappa">Harappa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dholavira" title="Dholavira">Dholavira</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kalibangan" title="Kalibangan">Kalibangan</a>, and relying on varied forms of subsistence, the civilisation engaged robustly in crafts production and wide-ranging trade.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009181_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009181-99">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the period 2000–500&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span>, many regions of the subcontinent transitioned from the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> cultures to the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> ones.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009255_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-101">[88]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>, the oldest scriptures associated with <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009186–187_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009186–187-102">[89]</a></sup> were composed during this period,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel200368–69_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel200368–69-103">[90]</a></sup> and historians have analysed these to posit a <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic culture</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Punjab_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Punjab region">Punjab region</a> and the upper <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Gangetic Plain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009255_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-101">[88]</a></sup> Most historians also consider this period to have encompassed several waves of <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Aryan migration">Indo-Aryan migration</a> into the subcontinent from the north-west.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009186–187_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009186–187-102">[89]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Caste_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Caste system">caste system</a>, which created a hierarchy of priests, warriors, and free peasants, but which excluded indigenous peoples by labelling their occupations impure, arose during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441–43_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441–43-104">[91]</a></sup> On the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a>, archaeological evidence from this period suggests the existence of a chiefdom stage of political organisation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009255_101-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-101">[88]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">South India</a>, a progression to sedentary life is indicated by the large number of <a href="/wiki/Megalith" title="Megalith">megalithic</a> monuments dating from this period,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009250–251_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009250–251-105">[92]</a></sup> as well as by nearby traces of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irrigation_tanks" class="mw-redirect" title="Irrigation tanks">irrigation tanks</a>, and craft traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009250–251_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009250–251-105">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Cave_26,_Ajanta.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/220px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/330px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/440px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4100" data-file-height="2662"></a><figcaption>Cave 26 of the rock-cut <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In the late Vedic period, around the 6th century BCE, the small states and chiefdoms of the Ganges Plain and the north-western regions had consolidated into 16 major oligarchies and monarchies that were known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Mahajanapadas" title="Mahajanapadas">mahajanapadas</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009260–265_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009260–265-106">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200453–54_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200453–54-107">[94]</a></sup> The emerging urbanisation gave rise to non-Vedic religious movements, two of which became independent religions. <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> came into prominence during the life of its exemplar, <a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009312–313_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009312–313-108">[95]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, based on the teachings of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, attracted followers from all social classes excepting the middle class; chronicling the life of the Buddha was central to the beginnings of recorded history in India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200454–56_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200454–56-109">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199821_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199821-110">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199867–68_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199867–68-111">[98]</a></sup> In an age of increasing urban wealth, both religions held up <a href="/wiki/Nekkhamma" title="Nekkhamma">renunciation</a> as an ideal,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009300_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009300-112">[99]</a></sup> and both established long-lasting monastic traditions. Politically, by the 3rd century BCE, the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Magadha" title="Magadha">Magadha</a> had annexed or reduced other states to emerge as the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Mauryan Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009319_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009319-113">[100]</a></sup> The empire was once thought to have controlled most of the subcontinent except the far south, but its core regions are now thought to have been separated by large autonomous areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199878–79_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199878–79-114">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200470_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200470-115">[102]</a></sup> The Mauryan kings are known as much for their empire-building and determined management of public life as for <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a>'s renunciation of militarism and far-flung advocacy of the Buddhist <i><a href="/wiki/Dharma_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dharma (Buddhism)">dhamma</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009367_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009367-116">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200463_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200463-117">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Tamil_language" title="Tamil language">Tamil language</a> reveals that, between 200&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span> and 200&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span>, the southern peninsula was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Chera_dynasty" title="Chera dynasty">Cheras</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Cholas</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Pandya_dynasty" title="Pandya dynasty">Pandyas</a>, dynasties that <a href="/wiki/Indo-Roman_trade_relations" title="Indo-Roman trade relations">traded extensively with the Roman Empire</a> and with <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Asia">West</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199889–90_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199889–90-118">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009408–415_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009408–415-119">[106]</a></sup> In North India, Hinduism asserted patriarchal control within the family, leading to increased subordination of women.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199892–95_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199892–95-120">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009319_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009319-113">[100]</a></sup> By the 4th and 5th centuries, the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a> had created a complex system of administration and taxation in the greater Ganges Plain; this system became a model for later Indian kingdoms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200489–91_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200489–91-121">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009545_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-122">[109]</a></sup> Under the Guptas, a renewed Hinduism based on devotion, rather than the management of ritual, began to assert itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein199898–99_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199898–99-123">[110]</a></sup> This renewal was reflected in a flowering of <a href="/wiki/Sculpture_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Sculpture in the Indian subcontinent">sculpture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_India" title="Architecture of India">architecture</a>, which found patrons among an urban elite.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009545_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-122">[109]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_literature#Classical_Sanskrit_literature" title="Sanskrit literature">Classical Sanskrit literature</a> flowered as well, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of science and technology in the Indian subcontinent">Indian science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indian_astronomy" title="Indian astronomy">astronomy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ayurveda" title="Ayurveda">medicine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_mathematics" title="Indian mathematics">mathematics</a> made significant advances.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2009545_122-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-122">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_India">Medieval India</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:228px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG/152px-Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG" decoding="async" width="152" height="228" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG/228px-Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG/304px-Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG 2x" data-file-width="1728" data-file-height="2592"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Brihadeshwara_temple" class="mw-redirect" title="Brihadeshwara temple">Brihadeshwara temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thanjavur" title="Thanjavur">Thanjavur</a>, completed in 1010&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:154px;max-width:154px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:228px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/152px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg" decoding="async" width="152" height="228" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/228px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/304px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="2250"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Qutub_Minar" class="mw-redirect" title="Qutub Minar">Qutub Minar</a>, 73&nbsp;m (240&nbsp;ft) tall, completed by the <a href="/wiki/Sultan_of_Delhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Sultan of Delhi">Sultan of Delhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iltutmish" title="Iltutmish">Iltutmish</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Indian early medieval age, from 600 to 1200&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span>, is defined by regional kingdoms and cultural diversity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998132_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998132-124">[111]</a></sup> When <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harsha</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kannauj" title="Kannauj">Kannauj</a>, who ruled much of the Indo-Gangetic Plain from 606 to 647&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span>, attempted to expand southwards, he was defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty" title="Chalukya dynasty">Chalukya</a> ruler of the Deccan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120-125">[112]</a></sup> When his successor attempted to expand eastwards, he was defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pala</a> king of <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120-125">[112]</a></sup> When the Chalukyas attempted to expand southwards, they were defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Pallava_dynasty" title="Pallava dynasty">Pallavas</a> from farther south, who in turn were opposed by the <a href="/wiki/Pandya_dynasty" title="Pandya dynasty">Pandyas</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chola_dynasty" title="Chola dynasty">Cholas</a> from still farther south.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120_125-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119–120-125">[112]</a></sup> No ruler of this period was able to create an empire and consistently control lands much beyond their core region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998132_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998132-124">[111]</a></sup> During this time, pastoral peoples, whose land had been cleared to make way for the growing agricultural economy, were accommodated within caste society, as were new non-traditional ruling classes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998121–122_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998121–122-126">[113]</a></sup> The caste system consequently began to show regional differences.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998121–122_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998121–122-126">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 6th and 7th centuries, the first <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">devotional hymns</a> were created in the Tamil language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998123_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998123-127">[114]</a></sup> They were imitated all over India and led to both the resurgence of Hinduism and the development of all <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_India" title="Languages of India">modern languages of the subcontinent</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998123_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998123-127">[114]</a></sup> Indian royalty, big and small, and the temples they patronised drew citizens in great numbers to the capital cities, which became economic hubs as well.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998124_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998124-128">[115]</a></sup> Temple towns of various sizes began to appear everywhere as India underwent another urbanisation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998124_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998124-128">[115]</a></sup> By the 8th and 9th centuries, the effects were felt in Southeast Asia, as South Indian culture and political systems were exported to lands that became part of modern-day <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998127–128_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998127–128-129">[116]</a></sup> Indian merchants, scholars, and sometimes armies were involved in this transmission; Southeast Asians took the initiative as well, with many sojourning in Indian seminaries and translating Buddhist and Hindu texts into their languages.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998127–128_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998127–128-129">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the 10th century, Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans, using <a href="/wiki/Courser_(horse)" title="Courser (horse)">swift-horse</a> cavalry and raising vast armies united by ethnicity and religion, repeatedly overran South Asia's north-western plains, leading eventually to the establishment of the Islamic <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> in 1206.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELudden200268_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200268-130">[117]</a></sup> The sultanate was to control much of North India and to make many forays into South India. Although at first disruptive for the Indian elites, the sultanate largely left its vast non-Muslim subject population to its own laws and customs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200847_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200847-131">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066-132">[119]</a></sup> By repeatedly repulsing <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongol raiders</a> in the 13th century, the sultanate saved India from the devastation visited on West and Central Asia, setting the scene for centuries of <a href="/wiki/Human_migration" title="Human migration">migration</a> of fleeing soldiers, learned men, mystics, traders, artists, and artisans from that region into the subcontinent, thereby creating a syncretic Indo-Islamic culture in the north.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELudden200267_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200267-133">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850–51-134">[121]</a></sup> The sultanate's raiding and weakening of the regional kingdoms of South India paved the way for the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagara Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853-135">[122]</a></sup> Embracing a strong <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivite</a> tradition and building upon the military technology of the sultanate, the empire came to control much of peninsular India,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200612_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200612-136">[123]</a></sup> and was to influence South Indian society for long afterwards.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853-135">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_India">Early modern India</span></h3>
<p>In the early 16th century, northern India, then under mainly Muslim rulers,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb200180_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200180-137">[124]</a></sup> fell again to the superior mobility and firepower of a new generation of Central Asian warriors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998164_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998164-138">[125]</a></sup> The resulting <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> did not stamp out the local societies it came to rule. Instead, it balanced and pacified them through new administrative practices<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008115_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008115-139">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb200190–91_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200190–91-140">[127]</a></sup> and diverse and inclusive ruling elites,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617-141">[128]</a></sup> leading to more systematic, centralised, and uniform rule.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-142">[129]</a></sup> Eschewing tribal bonds and Islamic identity, especially under <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a>, the Mughals united their far-flung realms through loyalty, expressed through a Persianised culture, to an emperor who had near-divine status.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617-141">[128]</a></sup> The Mughal state's economic policies, deriving most revenues from agriculture<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008158_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008158-143">[130]</a></sup> and mandating that taxes be paid in the well-regulated silver currency,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998169_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998169-144">[131]</a></sup> caused peasants and artisans to enter larger markets.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152_142-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-142">[129]</a></sup> The relative peace maintained by the empire during much of the 17th century was a factor in India's economic expansion,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152_142-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-142">[129]</a></sup> resulting in greater patronage of <a href="/wiki/Mughal_painting" title="Mughal painting">painting</a>, literary forms, textiles, and <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008186_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008186-145">[132]</a></sup> Newly coherent social groups in northern and western India, such as the <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Marathas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rajput" title="Rajput">Rajputs</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikhs</a>, gained military and governing ambitions during Mughal rule, which, through collaboration or adversity, gave them both recognition and military experience.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623–24_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623–24-146">[133]</a></sup> Expanding commerce during Mughal rule gave rise to new Indian commercial and political elites along the coasts of southern and eastern India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623–24_146-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623–24-146">[133]</a></sup> As the empire disintegrated, many among these elites were able to seek and control their own affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008256_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008256-147">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:151px;max-width:151px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:99px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG/149px-Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG" decoding="async" width="149" height="99" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG/224px-Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG/298px-Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A distant view of the <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Agra_Fort" title="Agra Fort">Agra Fort</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:197px;max-width:197px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:99px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/195px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg" decoding="async" width="195" height="99" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/293px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/390px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5752" data-file-height="2923"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A two <a href="/wiki/Mohur" title="Mohur">mohur</a> Company gold coin, issued in 1835, the <a href="/wiki/Obverse_and_reverse" title="Obverse and reverse">obverse</a> inscribed "<a href="/wiki/William_IV" title="William IV">William IV</a>, King"</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>By the early 18th century, with the lines between commercial and political dominance being increasingly blurred, a number of European trading companies, including the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">English East India Company</a>, had established coastal outposts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-148">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200644–49_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200644–49-149">[136]</a></sup> The East India Company's control of the seas, greater resources, and more advanced military training and technology led it to increasingly assert its military strength and caused it to become attractive to a portion of the Indian elite; these factors were crucial in allowing the company to gain control over the <a href="/wiki/Bengal" title="Bengal">Bengal</a> region by 1765 and sideline the other European companies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb200198–100_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200198–100-150">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-148">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELudden2002128–132_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden2002128–132-151">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200651–55_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200651–55-152">[139]</a></sup> Its further access to the riches of Bengal and the subsequent increased strength and size of its army enabled it to annex or subdue most of India by the 1820s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200668–71_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200668–71-153">[140]</a></sup> India was then no longer exporting manufactured goods as it long had, but was instead supplying the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> with raw materials. Many historians consider this to be the onset of India's colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286_148-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-148">[135]</a></sup> By this time, with its economic power severely curtailed by the British parliament and having effectively been made an arm of British administration, the East India Company began more consciously to enter non-economic arenas, including education, social reform, and culture.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008289_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008289-154">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_India">Modern India</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="History of the Republic of India">History of the Republic of India</a></div>
<p>Historians consider India's modern age to have begun sometime between 1848 and 1885. The appointment in 1848 of <a href="/wiki/James_Broun-Ramsay,_1st_Marquess_of_Dalhousie" title="James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie">Lord Dalhousie</a> as Governor General of the East India Company set the stage for changes essential to a modern state. These included the consolidation and demarcation of sovereignty, the surveillance of the population, and the education of citizens. Technological changes—among them, railways, canals, and the telegraph—were introduced not long after their introduction in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb2001151–152_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb2001151–152-155">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200694–99_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200694–99-156">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown199483_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown199483-157">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPeers200650_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeers200650-158">[145]</a></sup> However, disaffection with the company also grew during this time and set off the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857" title="Indian Rebellion of 1857">Indian Rebellion of 1857</a>. Fed by diverse resentments and perceptions, including invasive British-style social reforms, harsh land taxes, and summary treatment of some rich landowners and princes, the rebellion rocked many regions of northern and central India and shook the foundations of Company rule.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006100–103_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006100–103-159">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown199485–86_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown199485–86-160">[147]</a></sup> Although the rebellion was suppressed by 1858, it led to the dissolution of the East India Company and the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">direct administration of India</a> by the British government. Proclaiming a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> and a gradual but limited British-style parliamentary system, the new rulers also protected princes and landed gentry as a feudal safeguard against future unrest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998239_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998239-161">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006103–108_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006103–108-162">[149]</a></sup> In the decades following, public life gradually emerged all over India, leading eventually to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> in 1885.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobb2001183_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb2001183-163">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarkar19831–4_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarkar19831–4-164">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECopland2001ix–x_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECopland2001ix–x-165">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006123_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006123-166">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rush of technology and the commercialisation of agriculture in the second half of the 19th century was marked by economic setbacks, and many small farmers became dependent on the whims of far-away markets.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998260_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998260-167">[154]</a></sup> There was an increase in the number of large-scale <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_India" title="Famine in India">famines</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein2010245_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein2010245-168">[155]</a></sup> and, despite the risks of infrastructure development borne by Indian taxpayers, little industrial employment was generated for Indians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein1998258_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998258-169">[156]</a></sup> There were also salutary effects: commercial cropping, especially in the newly canalled Punjab, led to increased food production for internal consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126-170">[157]</a></sup> The railway network provided critical famine relief,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697-171">[158]</a></sup> notably reduced the cost of moving goods,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697_171-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697-171">[158]</a></sup> and helped nascent Indian-owned industry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126_170-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126-170">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:166px;max-width:166px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:134px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/164px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="164" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/246px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/328px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1498" data-file-height="1223"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">1909 map of the British Indian Empire</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:182px;max-width:182px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:134px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Nehru_gandhi.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/180px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/270px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Nehru_gandhi.jpg/360px-Nehru_gandhi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="421" data-file-height="314"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> sharing a light moment with <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a>, Mumbai, 6 July 1946</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>After World War I, in which approximately <a href="/wiki/Indian_Army_during_World_War_I" title="Indian Army during World War I">one million Indians served</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006163_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006163-172">[159]</a></sup> a new period began. It was marked by <a href="/wiki/Montagu%E2%80%93Chelmsford_Reforms" title="Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms">British reforms</a> but also <a href="/wiki/Rowlatt_act" class="mw-redirect" title="Rowlatt act">repressive legislation</a>, by more strident Indian calls for self-rule, and by the beginnings of a <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent" class="mw-redirect" title="Nonviolent">nonviolent</a> movement of non-co-operation, of which <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> would become the leader and enduring symbol.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006167_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006167-173">[160]</a></sup> During the 1930s, slow legislative reform was enacted by the British; the Indian National Congress won victories in the resulting elections.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006195–197_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006195–197-174">[161]</a></sup> The next decade was beset with crises: <a href="/wiki/India_in_World_War_II" title="India in World War II">Indian participation in World War&nbsp;II</a>, the Congress's final push for non-co-operation, and an upsurge of <a href="/wiki/Muslim_nationalism_in_South_Asia" title="Muslim nationalism in South Asia">Muslim nationalism</a>. All were capped by the advent of independence in 1947, but tempered by the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India</a> into two states: India and Pakistan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006203_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006203-175">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vital to India's self-image as an independent nation was its constitution, completed in 1950, which put in place a secular and democratic republic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006231_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006231-176">[163]</a></sup> Per the <a href="/wiki/London_Declaration" title="London Declaration">London Declaration</a>, India retained its membership of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a>, becoming the first republic within it.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[164]</a></sup> Economic liberalisation, which <a href="/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India" title="Economic liberalisation in India">began in the 1980s</a> and the collaboration with Soviet Union for technical know-how,<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[165]</a></sup> has created a large urban middle class, transformed India into <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_growth_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate">one of the world's fastest-growing economies</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[166]</a></sup> and increased its geopolitical clout.
