Yet, India is also shaped by seemingly unyielding poverty, both rural and urban;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265–266-180">[167]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Religious_violence_in_India" title="Religious violence in India">religious</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caste-related_violence_in_India" title="Caste-related violence in India">caste-related violence</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006266–270_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006266–270-181">[168]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Naxalite" class="mw-redirect" title="Naxalite">Maoist-inspired Naxalite insurgencies</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006253_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006253-182">[169]</a></sup> and by <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir" title="Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir">separatism in Jammu and Kashmir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_Northeast_India" title="Insurgency in Northeast India">in Northeast India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006274_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006274-183">[170]</a></sup> It has unresolved territorial disputes with <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93India_relations#1960s" title="China–India relations">China</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248-184">[171]</a></sup> and with <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts" title="Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts">Pakistan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248-184">[171]</a></sup> India's sustained democratic freedoms are unique among the world's newer nations; however, in spite of its recent economic successes, freedom from want for its disadvantaged population remains a goal yet to be achieved.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-185">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_India" title="Geography of India">Geography of India</a></div>
<p>India accounts for the bulk of the Indian subcontinent, lying atop the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Plate" title="Indian Plate">Indian tectonic plate</a>, a part of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">Indo-Australian Plate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-186">[173]</a></sup> India's defining geological processes began 75 million years ago when the Indian Plate, then part of the southern supercontinent <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, began a north-eastward <a href="/wiki/Plate_tectonics" title="Plate tectonics">drift</a> caused by <a href="/wiki/Seafloor_spreading" title="Seafloor spreading">seafloor spreading</a> to its south-west, and later, south and south-east.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-186">[173]</a></sup> Simultaneously, the vast <a href="/wiki/Tethys_Ocean" title="Tethys Ocean">Tethyan</a> <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_crust" title="Oceanic crust">oceanic crust</a>, to its northeast, began to <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">subduct</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Plate" title="Eurasian Plate">Eurasian Plate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-186">[173]</a></sup> These dual processes, driven by convection in the Earth's <a href="/wiki/Mantle_(geology)" title="Mantle (geology)">mantle</a>, both created the Indian Ocean and caused the Indian <a href="/wiki/Continental_crust" title="Continental crust">continental crust</a> eventually to under-thrust Eurasia and to uplift the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-186">[173]</a></sup> Immediately south of the emerging Himalayas, plate movement created a vast crescent-shaped <a href="/wiki/Trough_(geology)" title="Trough (geology)">trough</a> that rapidly filled with river-borne sediment<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20237_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20237-187">[174]</a></sup> and now constitutes the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Indo-Gangetic Plain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000-188">[175]</a></sup> The original Indian plate makes its first appearance above the sediment in the ancient <a href="/wiki/Aravalli_range" class="mw-redirect" title="Aravalli range">Aravalli range</a>, which extends from the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Ridge" title="Delhi Ridge">Delhi Ridge</a> in a southwesterly direction. To the west lies the <a href="/wiki/Thar_Desert" title="Thar Desert">Thar Desert</a>, the eastern spread of which is checked by the Aravallis.<sup id="cite_ref-aravalli_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aravalli-189">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-prasad-aravalli_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prasad-aravalli-190">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fisher-aravalli_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fisher-aravalli-191">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:124px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/208px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG" decoding="async" width="208" height="125" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/312px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/416px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3857" data-file-height="2313"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Tungabhadra_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Tungabhadra river">Tungabhadra</a>, with rocky outcrops, flows into the peninsular <a href="/wiki/Krishna_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Krishna river">Krishna river</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003257_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003257-192">[179]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:123px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/208px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="123" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/312px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/416px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4094" data-file-height="2428"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Fishing boats lashed together in a <a href="/wiki/Creek_(tidal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Creek (tidal)">tidal creek</a> in <a href="/wiki/Anjarle" title="Anjarle">Anjarle</a> village, Maharashtra</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The remaining Indian Plate survives as <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">peninsular India</a>, the oldest and geologically most stable part of India. It extends as far north as the <a href="/wiki/Satpura_Range" title="Satpura Range">Satpura</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vindhya_Range" title="Vindhya Range">Vindhya</a> ranges in central India. These parallel chains run from the Arabian Sea coast in Gujarat in the west to the coal-rich <a href="/wiki/Chota_Nagpur_Plateau" title="Chota Nagpur Plateau">Chota Nagpur Plateau</a> in Jharkhand in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20238_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20238-193">[180]</a></sup> To the south, the remaining peninsular landmass, the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a>, is flanked on the west and east by coastal ranges known as the <a href="/wiki/Western_Ghats" title="Western Ghats">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ghats" title="Eastern Ghats">Eastern Ghats</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20239–10_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20239–10-194">[181]</a></sup> the plateau contains the country's oldest rock formations, some over one billion years old. Constituted in such fashion, India lies to the north of the equator between 6° 44′ and 35° 30′ north latitude<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[n]</a></sup> and 68° 7′ and 97° 25′ east longitude.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Information_and_Broadcasting20071_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Information_and_Broadcasting20071-196">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>India's coastline measures 7,517 kilometres (4,700&nbsp;mi) in length; of this distance, 5,423 kilometres (3,400&nbsp;mi) belong to peninsular India and 2,094 kilometres (1,300&nbsp;mi) to the Andaman, Nicobar, and Lakshadweep island chains.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-197">[183]</a></sup> According to the Indian naval hydrographic charts, the mainland coastline consists of the following: 43% sandy beaches; 11% rocky shores, including cliffs; and 46% <a href="/wiki/Mudflat" title="Mudflat">mudflats</a> or marshy shores.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006_197-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-197">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>Major Himalayan-origin rivers that substantially flow through India include the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a>, both of which drain into the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal" title="Bay of Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202315_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202315-198">[184]</a></sup> Important tributaries of the Ganges include the <a href="/wiki/Yamuna" title="Yamuna">Yamuna</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kosi_River" title="Kosi River">Kosi</a>; the latter's extremely low gradient, caused by long-term silt deposition, leads to severe floods and course changes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuff1993353_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuff1993353-199">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasuXavier2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidnXmLDgAAQBAJpgPA78_78]_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasuXavier2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidnXmLDgAAQBAJpgPA78_78]-200">[186]</a></sup> Major peninsular rivers, whose steeper gradients prevent their waters from flooding, include the <a href="/wiki/Godavari_River" title="Godavari River">Godavari</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mahanadi_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahanadi River">Mahanadi</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kaveri_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaveri River">Kaveri</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Krishna_River" title="Krishna River">Krishna</a>, which also drain into the Bay of Bengal;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202316_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202316-201">[187]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Narmada_River" title="Narmada River">Narmada</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tapti_River" title="Tapti River">Tapti</a>, which drain into the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Sea" title="Arabian Sea">Arabian Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202317_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202317-202">[188]</a></sup> Coastal features include the marshy <a href="/wiki/Rann_of_Kutch" title="Rann of Kutch">Rann of Kutch</a> of western India and the alluvial <a href="/wiki/Sundarbans" title="Sundarbans">Sundarbans</a> delta of eastern India; the latter is shared with Bangladesh.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202312_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202312-203">[189]</a></sup> India has two <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelagos</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Lakshadweep" title="Lakshadweep">Lakshadweep</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atoll" title="Atoll">coral atolls</a> off India's south-western coast; and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a volcanic chain in the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_Sea" title="Andaman Sea">Andaman Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202313_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202313-204">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India" title="Climate of India">Indian climate</a> is strongly influenced by the Himalayas and the Thar Desert, both of which drive the economically and culturally pivotal summer and winter <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394-205">[191]</a></sup> The Himalayas prevent cold Central Asian <a href="/wiki/Katabatic_wind" title="Katabatic wind">katabatic winds</a> from blowing in, keeping the bulk of the Indian subcontinent warmer than most locations at similar latitudes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPosey1994118_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPosey1994118-206">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWolpert20034_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert20034-207">[193]</a></sup> The Thar Desert plays a crucial role in attracting the moisture-laden south-west summer monsoon winds that, between June and October, provide the majority of India's rainfall.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394_205-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391–394-205">[191]</a></sup> Four major climatic groupings predominate in India: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Tropical_wet" title="Climate of India">tropical wet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Arid_and_semi-arid_regions" title="Climate of India">tropical dry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Subtropical_humid" title="Climate of India">subtropical humid</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_India#Mountain" title="Climate of India">montane</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden199697_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden199697-208">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>Temperatures in India have risen by 0.7&nbsp;°C (1.3&nbsp;°F) between 1901 and 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_India" title="Climate change in India">Climate change in India</a> is often thought to be the cause. The <a href="/wiki/Retreat_of_glaciers_since_1850" title="Retreat of glaciers since 1850">retreat of Himalayan glaciers</a> has adversely affected the <a href="/wiki/Volumetric_flow_rate" title="Volumetric flow rate">flow rate</a> of the major Himalayan rivers, including the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra" class="mw-redirect" title="Brahmaputra">Brahmaputra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-210">[196]</a></sup> According to some current projections, the number and severity of droughts in India will have markedly increased by the end of the present century.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Forestry_in_India" title="Forestry in India">Forestry in India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_India" title="Wildlife of India">Wildlife of India</a></div>
<p>India is a <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Megadiverse country">megadiverse country</a>, a term employed for 17 countries which display high <a href="/wiki/Biological_diversity" class="mw-redirect" title="Biological diversity">biological diversity</a> and contain many species exclusively <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_(ecology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Indigenous (ecology)">indigenous</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Endemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic">endemic</a>, to them.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[198]</a></sup> India is a <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitat</a> for 8.6% of all <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammal</a> species, 13.7% of <a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">bird</a> species, 7.9% of <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptile</a> species, 6% of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species, 12.2% of <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">fish</a> species, and 6.0% of all <a href="/wiki/Flowering_plant" title="Flowering plant">flowering plant</a> species.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Puri_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Puri-214">[200]</a></sup> Fully a third of Indian plant species are endemic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasak198324_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasak198324-215">[201]</a></sup> India also contains four of the world's 34 <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot" title="Biodiversity hotspot">biodiversity hotspots</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN-India_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-India-83">[70]</a></sup> or regions that display significant habitat loss in the presence of high endemism.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[o]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018-216">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to official statistics, India's <a href="/wiki/Forest_cover" title="Forest cover">forest cover</a> is 713,789&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (275,595&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), which is 21.71% of the country's total land area.<sup id="cite_ref-ISFR_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ISFR-84">[71]</a></sup> It can be subdivided further into broad categories of <i>canopy density</i>, or the proportion of the area of a forest covered by its <a href="/wiki/Tree_canopy" class="mw-redirect" title="Tree canopy">tree canopy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-218">[203]</a></sup> <i>Very dense forest</i>, whose <i>canopy density</i> is greater than 70%, occupies 3.02% of India's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_218-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-218">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-219">[204]</a></sup> It predominates in the <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forest">tropical moist forest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Andaman_Islands" title="Andaman Islands">Andaman Islands</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Ghats" title="Western Ghats">Western Ghats</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northeast_India" title="Northeast India">Northeast India</a>. <i>Moderately dense forest</i>, whose canopy density is between 40% and 70%, occupies 9.39% of India's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_218-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-218">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_219-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-219">[204]</a></sup> It predominates in the <a href="/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest" title="Temperate coniferous forest">temperate coniferous forest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Himalaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Himalaya">Himalayas</a>, the moist deciduous <i><a href="/wiki/Shorea_robusta" title="Shorea robusta">sal</a></i> forest of eastern India, and the dry deciduous <a href="/wiki/Teak" title="Teak">teak</a> forest of central and southern India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch200111–12_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200111–12-220">[205]</a></sup> <i>Open forest</i>, whose canopy density is between 10% and 40%, occupies 9.26% of India's land area.<sup id="cite_ref-Jha2018_218-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jha2018-218">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-indiaforest_219-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-indiaforest-219">[204]</a></sup> India has two natural zones of <a href="/wiki/Deserts_and_xeric_shrublands" title="Deserts and xeric shrublands">thorn forest</a>, one in the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan Plateau</a>, immediately east of the Western Ghats, and the other in the western part of the Indo-Gangetic plain, now turned into rich agricultural land by irrigation, its features no longer visible.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch200112_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200112-221">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the Indian subcontinent's notable indigenous trees are the <a href="/wiki/Astringent" title="Astringent">astringent</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Azadirachta_indica" title="Azadirachta indica">Azadirachta indica</a></i>, or <i>neem</i>, which is widely used in rural Indian <a href="/wiki/Herbal_medicine" title="Herbal medicine">herbal medicine</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Goyal2006_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goyal2006-222">[207]</a></sup> and the luxuriant <i><a href="/wiki/Ficus_religiosa" title="Ficus religiosa">Ficus religiosa</a></i>, or <i>peepul</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Hughes2013_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hughes2013-223">[208]</a></sup> which is displayed on the ancient seals of <a href="/wiki/Mohenjo-daro" title="Mohenjo-daro">Mohenjo-daro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-AmeriCostello2018_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AmeriCostello2018-224">[209]</a></sup> and under which <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a> is recorded in the <a href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" class="mw-redirect" title="Pāli Canon">Pali canon</a> to have sought enlightenment.<sup id="cite_ref-Gwynne2011_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gwynne2011-225">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Indian species have descended from those of <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">Gondwana</a>, the southern <a href="/wiki/Supercontinent" title="Supercontinent">supercontinent</a> from which India separated more than 100 million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrameOwen2002142_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrameOwen2002142-226">[211]</a></sup> India's subsequent collision with Eurasia set off a mass exchange of species. However, <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Traps" title="Deccan Traps">volcanism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_variability_and_change" title="Climate variability and change">climatic changes</a> later caused the extinction of many endemic Indian forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaranth2006_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranth2006-227">[212]</a></sup> Still later, mammals entered India from Asia through two <a href="/wiki/Zoogeographical" class="mw-redirect" title="Zoogeographical">zoogeographical</a> passes flanking the Himalayas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch200114_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200114-228">[213]</a></sup> This had the effect of lowering endemism among India's mammals, which stands at 12.6%, contrasting with 45.8% among reptiles and 55.8% among amphibians.<sup id="cite_ref-Puri_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Puri-214">[200]</a></sup> Among endemics are the vulnerable<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[214]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nilgiri_Langur" class="mw-redirect" title="Nilgiri Langur">hooded leaf monkey</a><sup id="cite_ref-itis_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-itis-230">[215]</a></sup> and the threatened<sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-231">[216]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Duttaphrynus_beddomii" title="Duttaphrynus beddomii">Beddome's toad</a><sup id="cite_ref-IUCN_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IUCN-231">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[217]</a></sup> of the Western Ghats.
</p><p>India contains 172 <a href="/wiki/World_Conservation_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="World Conservation Union">IUCN</a>-designated <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_in_India" title="List of endangered animals in India">threatened animal species</a>, or 2.9% of endangered forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMace19944_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMace19944-233">[218]</a></sup> These include the endangered <a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a> and the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin" title="South Asian river dolphin">Ganges river dolphin</a>. <a href="/wiki/Critically_endangered" class="mw-redirect" title="Critically endangered">Critically endangered</a> species include the <a href="/wiki/Gharial" title="Gharial">gharial</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Crocodilian" class="mw-redirect" title="Crocodilian">crocodilian</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Great_Indian_bustard" title="Great Indian bustard">great Indian bustard</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_white-rumped_vulture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian white-rumped vulture">Indian white-rumped vulture</a>, which has become nearly extinct by having ingested the carrion of <a href="/wiki/Diclofenac" title="Diclofenac">diclofenac</a>-treated cattle.<sup id="cite_ref-LovetteFitzpatrick2016_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LovetteFitzpatrick2016-234">[219]</a></sup> Before they were extensively used for agriculture and cleared for human settlement, the thorn forests of Punjab were mingled at intervals with open grasslands that were grazed by large herds of blackbuck preyed on by the <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah" title="Asiatic cheetah">Asiatic cheetah</a>; the blackbuck, no longer extant in Punjab, is now severely endangered in India, and the cheetah is extinct.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETritsch200115_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200115-235">[220]</a></sup> The pervasive and ecologically devastating human encroachment of recent decades has critically endangered Indian wildlife. In response, the system of <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="National parks of India">national parks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_India" title="Protected areas of India">protected areas</a>, first established in 1935, was expanded substantially. In 1972, India enacted the <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_Protection_Act_of_1972" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife Protection Act of 1972">Wildlife Protection Act</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environment_and_Forests_1972_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environment_and_Forests_1972-236">[221]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Project_Tiger" title="Project Tiger">Project Tiger</a> to safeguard crucial wilderness; the Forest Conservation Act was enacted in 1980 and amendments added in 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Environment_and_Forests1988_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Environment_and_Forests1988-237">[222]</a></sup> India hosts <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_sanctuaries_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Wildlife sanctuaries of India">more than five hundred wildlife sanctuaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserves_of_India" title="Biosphere reserves of India">eighteen<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>biosphere reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[223]</a></sup> four of which are part of the <a href="/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves">World Network of Biosphere Reserves</a>; <a href="/wiki/List_of_Ramsar_sites_in_India" title="List of Ramsar sites in India">seventy-five wetlands</a> are registered under the <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">Ramsar Convention</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="India has the majority of the world's wild tigers, approximately 3,170 in 2022.[225]"><img alt="India has the majority of the world's wild tigers, approximately 3,170 in 2022.[225]" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/270px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/405px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/540px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4057" data-file-height="2705"></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">India has the majority of the world's wild <a href="/wiki/Tiger" title="Tiger">tigers</a>, approximately 3,170 in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[225]</a></sup></div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 180px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Axis_axis_(Nagarhole,_2010).jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="A chital (Axis axis) stag in the Nagarhole National Park in a region covered by a moderately dense[p] forest"><img alt="A chital (Axis axis) stag in the Nagarhole National Park in a region covered by a moderately dense[p] forest" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/270px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="120" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/405px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/540px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2134"></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">A <a href="/wiki/Chital" title="Chital">chital</a> (<i>Axis axis</i>) stag in the <a href="/wiki/Nagarhole_National_Park" title="Nagarhole National Park">Nagarhole National Park</a> in a region covered by a moderately dense<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[p]</a></sup> forest</div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 164.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 162.66666666667px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Maharajah_Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo_with_cheetah_kill_1948_BNHS.jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="Three of the last Asiatic cheetahs in India were shot dead in 1948 in Surguja district, Madhya Pradesh, Central India by Maharajah Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo. 			<div class="gallerytext">Three of the last <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah" title="Asiatic cheetah">Asiatic cheetahs</a> in India were shot dead in 1948 in <a href="/wiki/Surguja_district" title="Surguja district">Surguja district</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh" title="Madhya Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_India" title="Central India">Central India</a> by Maharajah <a href="/wiki/Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo" title="Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo">Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo</a>. The young male <a href="/wiki/Cheetah" title="Cheetah">cheetahs</a>, all from the same litter, were sitting together when they were shot at night.</div>
		</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics_and_government">Politics and government</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_India" title="Politics of India">Politics of India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Rajagopal_speaking_to_25,000_people,_Janadesh_2007,_India.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/208px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/312px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/416px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">As part of <a href="/wiki/Janadesh_2007" title="Janadesh 2007">Janadesh 2007</a>, 25,000 pro-<a href="/wiki/Land_reform_in_India" title="Land reform in India">land reform</a> <a href="/wiki/Landless" class="mw-redirect" title="Landless">landless</a> people in <a href="/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh" title="Madhya Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a> listen to <a href="/wiki/Rajagopal_P._V." title="Rajagopal P. V.">Rajagopal P. V.</a><sup id="cite_ref-Johnston2019_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Johnston2019-242">[226]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party system</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurnellCalvert1999125_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurnellCalvert1999125-243">[227]</a></sup> India has six<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>recognised <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_India#National_parties" title="List of political parties in India">national parties</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Indian_National_Congress" title="Indian National Congress">Indian National Congress</a> (INC) and the <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">Bharatiya Janata Party</a> (BJP), and more than 50<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_India#State_parties" title="List of political parties in India">regional parties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElection_Commission_of_India_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElection_Commission_of_India-244">[228]</a></sup> The Congress is considered <a href="/wiki/Centrism" title="Centrism">centre</a> in Indian <a href="/wiki/Political_culture" title="Political culture">political culture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[229]</a></sup> and the BJP <a href="/wiki/Right-wing_politics" title="Right-wing politics">right-wing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalikSingh1992318–336_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalikSingh1992318–336-246">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanerjee20053118_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanerjee20053118-247">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[232]</a></sup> For most of the period between 1950—when India first became a republic—and the late 1980s, the Congress held a majority in the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">Parliament</a>. Since then, however, it has increasingly shared the political stage with the BJP,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarkar200784_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarkar200784-249">[233]</a></sup> as well as with powerful regional parties which have often forced the creation of multi-party <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">coalition governments</a> at the centre.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChander2004117_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChander2004117-250">[234]</a></sup> India was 2023 the 19th most electoral <a href="/wiki/Democracy_in_Asia" title="Democracy in Asia">democratic country in Asia</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/V-Dem_Democracy_indices" class="mw-redirect" title="V-Dem Democracy indices">V-Dem Democracy indices</a> .<sup id="cite_ref-vdem_dataset_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vdem_dataset-251">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Republic of India's first three general elections, in <a href="/wiki/1951_Indian_general_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1951 Indian general election">1951</a>, <a href="/wiki/1957_Indian_general_election" title="1957 Indian general election">1957</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election" title="1962 Indian general election">1962</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pandit_Jawaharlal_Nehru" class="mw-redirect" title="Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru">Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru</a>-led Congress won easy victories. On Nehru's death in 1964, <a href="/wiki/Lal_Bahadur_Shastri" title="Lal Bahadur Shastri">Lal Bahadur Shastri</a> briefly became prime minister; he was succeeded, after his own unexpected death in 1966, by Nehru's daughter <a href="/wiki/Indira_Gandhi" title="Indira Gandhi">Indira Gandhi</a>, who went on to lead the Congress to election victories in <a href="/wiki/1967_Indian_general_election" title="1967 Indian general election">1967</a> and <a href="/wiki/1971_Indian_general_election" title="1971 Indian general election">1971</a>. Following public discontent with the <a href="/wiki/The_Emergency_(India)" title="The Emergency (India)">state of emergency</a> she declared in 1975, the Congress was voted out of power in <a href="/wiki/1977_Indian_general_election" title="1977 Indian general election">1977</a>; the then-new <a href="/wiki/Janata_Party" title="Janata Party">Janata Party</a>, which had opposed the emergency, was voted in. Its government lasted just over two years. There were two prime ministers during this period; <a href="/wiki/Morarji_Desai" title="Morarji Desai">Morarji Desai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charan_Singh" title="Charan Singh">Charan Singh</a>. Voted back into power in 1980, the Congress saw a change in leadership in 1984, when Indira Gandhi was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi" title="Assassination of Indira Gandhi">assassinated</a>; she was succeeded by her son <a href="/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi" title="Rajiv Gandhi">Rajiv Gandhi</a>, who won an easy victory in the general elections <a href="/wiki/1984_Indian_general_election" title="1984 Indian general election">later that year</a>. The Congress was voted out again in <a href="/wiki/1989_Indian_general_election" title="1989 Indian general election">1989</a> when a <a href="/wiki/National_Front_(India)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Front (India)">National Front</a> coalition, led by the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Janata_Dal" title="Janata Dal">Janata Dal</a> in alliance with the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)" title="Communist Party of India (Marxist)">Left Front</a>, won the elections; that government too proved relatively short-lived, lasting just under two years. There were two prime ministers during this period; <a href="/wiki/V.P._Singh" class="mw-redirect" title="V.P. Singh">V.P. Singh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chandra_Shekhar" title="Chandra Shekhar">Chandra Shekhar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhambhri1992118,_143_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhambhri1992118,_143-252">[236]</a></sup> Elections were held again in <a href="/wiki/1991_Indian_general_election" title="1991 Indian general election">1991</a>; no party won an absolute majority. The Congress, as the largest single party, was able to form a <a href="/wiki/Minority_government" title="Minority government">minority government</a> led by <a href="/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao" title="P. V. Narasimha Rao">P. V. Narasimha Rao</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/208px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/312px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/416px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4096" data-file-height="2731"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">US president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> addresses the <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(India)" title="Member of Parliament (India)">members</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">Parliament of India</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a> in November 2010.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>A two-year period of political turmoil followed the general election of <a href="/wiki/1996_Indian_general_election" title="1996 Indian general election">1996</a>. Several short-lived alliances shared power at the centre. The BJP formed a government briefly in 1996; it was followed by two comparatively long-lasting <a href="/wiki/United_Front_(India)" title="United Front (India)">United Front</a> coalitions, which depended on external support. There were two prime ministers during this period; <a href="/wiki/H.D._Deve_Gowda" class="mw-redirect" title="H.D. Deve Gowda">H.D. Deve Gowda</a> and <a href="/wiki/I.K._Gujral" class="mw-redirect" title="I.K. Gujral">I.K. Gujral</a>. In <a href="/wiki/1998_Indian_general_election" title="1998 Indian general election">1998</a>, the BJP was able to form a successful coalition, the <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance" title="National Democratic Alliance">National Democratic Alliance</a> (NDA). Led by <a href="/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee" title="Atal Bihari Vajpayee">Atal Bihari Vajpayee</a>, the NDA became the first non-Congress, <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">coalition government</a> to complete a five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunleavyDiwakarDunleavy2007_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunleavyDiwakarDunleavy2007-254">[238]</a></sup> Again in the <a href="/wiki/2004_Indian_general_election" title="2004 Indian general election">2004 Indian general elections</a>, no party won an absolute majority, but the Congress emerged as the largest single party, forming another successful coalition: the <a href="/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance" title="United Progressive Alliance">United Progressive Alliance</a> (UPA). It had the support of <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_politics" title="Left-wing politics">left-leaning</a> parties and MPs who opposed the BJP. The UPA returned to power in the <a href="/wiki/2009_Indian_general_election" title="2009 Indian general election">2009 general election</a> with increased numbers, and it no longer required external support from <a href="/wiki/List_of_Communist_Parties_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Communist Parties in India">India's communist parties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004384_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004384-255">[239]</a></sup> That year, <a href="/wiki/Manmohan_Singh" title="Manmohan Singh">Manmohan Singh</a> became the first prime minister since <a href="/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru" title="Jawaharlal Nehru">Jawaharlal Nehru</a> in <a href="/wiki/1957_Indian_general_election" title="1957 Indian general election">1957</a> and <a href="/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election" title="1962 Indian general election">1962</a> to be re-elected to a consecutive five-year term.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Standard2009_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Standard2009-256">[240]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2014_Indian_general_election" title="2014 Indian general election">2014 general election</a>, the BJP became the first political party since 1984 to win a majority and govern without the support of other parties.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[241]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election" title="2019 Indian general election">2019 general election</a>, the BJP was victorious again. The incumbent prime minister is <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a>, a former <a href="/wiki/Chief_minister_(India)" title="Chief minister (India)">chief minister</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>. On 22 July 2022, <a href="/wiki/Droupadi_Murmu" title="Droupadi Murmu">Droupadi Murmu</a> was <a href="/wiki/2022_Indian_presidential_election" title="2022 Indian presidential election">elected</a> India's 15th president and took the oath of office on 25 July 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">Constitution of India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/208px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="138" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/312px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/416px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2710" data-file-height="1798"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Rashtrapati_Bhavan" title="Rashtrapati Bhavan">Rashtrapati Bhavan</a>, the official residence of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">President of India</a>, was designed by British architects <a href="/wiki/Edwin_Lutyens" title="Edwin Lutyens">Edwin Lutyens</a> and <a href="/wiki/Herbert_Baker" title="Herbert Baker">Herbert Baker</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Viceroy_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Viceroy of India">Viceroy of India</a>, and constructed between 1911 and 1931 during the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bremner2016_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bremner2016-259">[243]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>India is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federation</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> governed under the Constitution of India—the country's supreme legal document. It is a constitutional republic.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Federalism_in_India" title="Federalism in India">Federalism in India</a> defines the power distribution between the union and the <a href="/wiki/States_and_territories_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="States and territories of India">states</a>. The Constitution of India, which came into effect on 26 January 1950,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPylee2003a4_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPylee2003a4-260">[244]</a></sup> originally stated India to be a "<a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liberal_democracy" title="Liberal democracy">democratic</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>;" this characterisation was amended in 1971 to "a sovereign, <a href="/wiki/Socialist" class="mw-redirect" title="Socialist">socialist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a>, democratic republic".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt1998421_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt1998421-261">[245]</a></sup> India's form of government, traditionally described as "quasi-federal" with a strong centre and weak states,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWheare198028_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheare198028-262">[246]</a></sup> has grown increasingly federal since the late 1990s as a result of political, economic, and social changes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEcheverri-Gent200219–20_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEcheverri-Gent200219–20-263">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESinha200425_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESinha200425-264">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1141396924">.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols-left{float:left;clear:left;margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols-none{float:none;clear:none;margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols-center{float:none;clear:none;margin:0.5em auto}.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols .infobox-title{font-size:120%}.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols .infobox-subheader{font-weight:bold;background-color:#cddeff}.mw-parser-output .ib-region-symbols-island{font-weight:bold;background-color:#cef2e0}</style><table class="infobox ib-region-symbols"><caption class="infobox-title"><a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_India" title="National symbols of India">National symbols</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005-1">[1]</a></sup></caption><tbody><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Emblem</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/State_Emblem_of_India" title="State Emblem of India">Sarnath Lion Capital</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Anthem</th><td class="infobox-data"><i><a href="/wiki/Jana_Gana_Mana" title="Jana Gana Mana">Jana Gana Mana</a></i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Song</th><td class="infobox-data">"<a href="/wiki/Vande_Mataram" title="Vande Mataram">Vande Mataram</a>"</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Language</th><td class="infobox-data">None<sup id="cite_ref-Times_News_Network_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Times_News_Network-265">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NoneNtl_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NoneNtl-266">[250]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Press_Trust_of_India_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Press_Trust_of_India-267">[251]</a></sup></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee_sign" title="Indian rupee sign">₹</a> (<a href="/wiki/Indian_rupee" title="Indian rupee">Indian rupee</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Calendar</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Indian_national_calendar" title="Indian national calendar">Shaka</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Bird</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Indian_peafowl" title="Indian peafowl">Indian peafowl</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Flower</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera" title="Nelumbo nucifera">Lotus</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Fruit</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Mango" title="Mango">Mango</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Mammal</th><td class="infobox-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Bengal_tiger" title="Bengal tiger">Bengal tiger</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin" title="South Asian river dolphin">River dolphin</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Tree</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Banyan" title="Banyan">Banyan</a></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">River</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The Government of India comprises three branches:<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[252]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a>: The <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">President of India</a> is the ceremonial <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200731_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-269">[253]</a></sup> who is elected indirectly for a five-year term by an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(India)" title="Electoral College (India)">electoral college</a> comprising members of national and state legislatures.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007138_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007138-270">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970112_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970112-271">[255]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India" title="Prime Minister of India">Prime Minister of India</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and exercises most <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma1950_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-272">[256]</a></sup> Appointed by the president,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007162_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-273">[257]</a></sup> the prime minister is by convention supported by the <a href="/wiki/Political_party" title="Political party">party</a> or <a href="/wiki/Political_alliance" class="mw-redirect" title="Political alliance">political alliance</a> having a majority of seats in the lower house of parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma1950_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-272">[256]</a></sup> The executive of the Indian government consists of the president, the <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_India" title="Vice President of India">vice-president</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers" title="Union Council of Ministers">Union Council of Ministers</a>—with the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_(government)" title="Cabinet (government)">cabinet</a> being its executive committee—headed by the prime minister. Any minister holding a portfolio must be a member of one of the houses of parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200731_269-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-269">[253]</a></sup> In the Indian parliamentary system, the executive is subordinate to the legislature; the prime minister and their council are directly responsible to the lower house of the parliament. <a href="/wiki/Civil_Services_of_India" title="Civil Services of India">Civil servants</a> act as permanent executives and all decisions of the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive</a> are implemented by them.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMathew2003524_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMathew2003524-274">[258]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislature</a>: The legislature of India is the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_India" title="Parliament of India">parliament</a>. Operating under a <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster-style</a> parliamentary system, it comprises an upper house called the <a href="/wiki/Rajya_Sabha" title="Rajya Sabha">Rajya Sabha</a> (Council of States) and a lower house called the <a href="/wiki/Lok_Sabha" title="Lok Sabha">Lok Sabha</a> (House of the People).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970127_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970127-275">[259]</a></sup> The Rajya Sabha is a permanent body of 245<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>members who serve staggered six-year terms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007161_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007161-276">[260]</a></sup> Most are elected indirectly by the <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">state and union territorial</a> legislatures in numbers proportional to their state's share of the national population.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007162_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-273">[257]</a></sup> All but two of the Lok Sabha's 545<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>members are elected directly by popular vote; they represent <a href="/wiki/Single-member_constituency" class="mw-redirect" title="Single-member constituency">single-member constituencies</a> for five-year<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>terms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007143_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007143-277">[261]</a></sup> Two seats of parliament, <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian_reserved_seats_in_the_Lok_Sabha" title="Anglo-Indian reserved seats in the Lok Sabha">reserved</a> for <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Indian" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglo-Indian">Anglo-Indians</a> in the article 331, have been scrapped.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[263]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judiciary</a>: India has a three-tier<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>unitary <a href="/wiki/Judicial_independence" title="Judicial independence">independent judiciary</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-280">[264]</a></sup> comprising the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India" title="Supreme Court of India">supreme court</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India" title="Chief Justice of India">Chief Justice of India</a>, 25<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span><a href="/wiki/High_courts_of_India" title="High courts of India">high courts</a>, and a large number of trial courts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-280">[264]</a></sup> The supreme court has <a href="/wiki/Original_jurisdiction" title="Original jurisdiction">original jurisdiction</a> over cases involving <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_rights_in_India" title="Fundamental rights in India">fundamental rights</a> and over disputes between states and the centre and has <a href="/wiki/Appellate_jurisdiction" class="mw-redirect" title="Appellate jurisdiction">appellate jurisdiction</a> over the high courts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2007238,_255_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007238,_255-281">[265]</a></sup> It has the power to both strike down union or state laws which contravene the constitution<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESripati1998423–424_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESripati1998423–424-282">[266]</a></sup> and invalidate any government action it deems unconstitutional.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPylee2003b314_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPylee2003b314-283">[267]</a></sup></li></ul>
<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_India" title="Administrative divisions of India">Administrative divisions of India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Political_integration_of_India" title="Political integration of India">Political integration of India</a></div>
<p>India is a federal union comprising 28 <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">states</a> and 8 <a href="/wiki/Union_territory" title="Union territory">union territories</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-21">[14]</a></sup> All states, as well as the union territories of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)" title="Puducherry (union territory)">Puducherry</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Delhi" title="Delhi">National Capital Territory of Delhi</a>, have elected legislatures and governments following the Westminster system of governance. The remaining five union territories are directly ruled by the central government through appointed administrators. In 1956, under the <a href="/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956" title="States Reorganisation Act, 1956">States Reorganisation Act</a>, states were reorganised on a linguistic basis.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200749_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200749-284">[268]</a></sup> There are over a quarter of a million local government bodies at city, town, block, district and village levels.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="noresize" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Political_map_of_India_EN.svg/330px-Political_map_of_India_EN.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="387" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Political_map_of_India_EN.svg/495px-Political_map_of_India_EN.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Political_map_of_India_EN.svg/660px-Political_map_of_India_EN.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1594" data-file-height="1868" usemap="#ImageMap_0a92c15b27d2b375" resource="/wiki/File:Political_map_of_India_EN.svg"></span><a href="/wiki/File:Political_map_of_India_EN.svg" class="mw-file-magnify"></a><map name="ImageMap_0a92c15b27d2b375"><area href="/wiki/Afghanistan" shape="rect" coords="0,36,56,42" alt="Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan"><area href="/wiki/Myanmar" shape="rect" coords="281,203,321,210" alt="Myanmar" title="Myanmar"><area href="/wiki/China" shape="rect" coords="228,94,282,105" alt="China" title="China"><area href="/wiki/Tajikistan" shape="rect" coords="2,7,47,14" alt="Tajikistan" <h2><span id="Foreign.2C_economic_and_strategic_relations"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign,_economic_and_strategic_relations">Foreign, economic and strategic relations</span></h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_India" title="Foreign relations of India">Foreign relations of India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces" title="Indian Armed Forces">Indian Armed Forces</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Jawaharlal_Nehru,_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/208px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="130" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/312px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg
