</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_India" title="Architecture of India">Architecture of India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:240px;max-width:240px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:157px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg/238px-Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg" decoding="async" width="238" height="158" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg/357px-Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg/476px-Aks_The_Reflection_Taj_Mahal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Taj Mahal from across the <a href="/wiki/Yamuna_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Yamuna river">Yamuna river</a> showing two outlying red sandstone buildings, a mosque on the right (west) and a <i>jawab</i> (response) thought to have been built for architectural balance</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Much of Indian architecture, including the <a href="/wiki/Taj_Mahal" title="Taj Mahal">Taj Mahal</a>, other works of <a href="/wiki/Mughal_architecture" title="Mughal architecture">Indo-Islamic Mughal architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_architecture" title="Dravidian architecture">South Indian architecture</a>, blends ancient local traditions with imported styles.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuiper2010296–329_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper2010296–329-435">[416]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indian_vernacular_architecture" title="Indian vernacular architecture">Vernacular architecture</a> is also regional in its flavours. <i><a href="/wiki/Vastu_shastra" title="Vastu shastra">Vastu shastra</a></i>, literally "science of construction" or "architecture" and ascribed to <a href="/wiki/Mamuni_Mayan" title="Mamuni Mayan">Mamuni Mayan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESilverman200720_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESilverman200720-436">[417]</a></sup> explores how the laws of nature affect human dwellings;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKumar20005_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumar20005-437">[418]</a></sup> it employs precise geometry and directional alignments to reflect perceived cosmic constructs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoberts200473_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoberts200473-438">[419]</a></sup> As applied in <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">Hindu temple architecture</a>, it is influenced by the <i><a href="/wiki/Shilpa_Shastras" title="Shilpa Shastras">Shilpa Shastras</a></i>, a series of foundational texts whose basic mythological form is the <i>Vastu-Purusha mandala</i>, a square that embodied the "<a href="/wiki/Absolute_(philosophy)" title="Absolute (philosophy)">absolute</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELangMoleski2010151–152_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELangMoleski2010151–152-439">[420]</a></sup> The Taj Mahal, built in <a href="/wiki/Agra" title="Agra">Agra</a> between 1631 and 1648 by orders of <a href="/wiki/Mughal_emperors" class="mw-redirect" title="Mughal emperors">Mughal emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Shah_Jahan" title="Shah Jahan">Shah Jahan</a> in memory of his wife, has been described in the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_List" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO World Heritage List">UNESCO World Heritage List</a> as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally admired masterpieces of the world's heritage".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Educational,_Scientific,_and_Cultural_Organisation_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Educational,_Scientific,_and_Cultural_Organisation-440">[421]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indo-Saracenic_Revival_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture">Indo-Saracenic Revival architecture</a>, developed by the British in the late 19th century, drew on <a href="/wiki/Indo-Islamic_architecture" title="Indo-Islamic architecture">Indo-Islamic architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChopra201146_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChopra201146-441">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_literature" title="Indian literature">Indian literature</a></div>
<p>The earliest literature in India, composed between 1500&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span> and 1200&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span>, was in the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoibergRamchandani2000_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoibergRamchandani2000-442">[423]</a></sup> Major works of <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_literature" title="Sanskrit literature">Sanskrit literature</a> include the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1500&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>), the <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">epics</a>: <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahābhārata</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 400&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 400&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span> and later); <i>Abhijñānaśākuntalam</i> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Recognition_of_%C5%9Aakuntal%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="The Recognition of Śakuntalā">The Recognition of Śakuntalā</a></i>), and other dramas of <a href="/wiki/K%C4%81lid%C4%81sa" class="mw-redirect" title="Kālidāsa">Kālidāsa</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 5th century&nbsp;<span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_Classical_poetry" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanskrit Classical poetry">Mahākāvya</a></i> poetry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnson2008_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnson2008-443">[424]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonell20041–40_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonell20041–40-444">[425]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKālidāsaJohnson2001_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKālidāsaJohnson2001-445">[426]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Tamil_literature" title="Tamil literature">Tamil literature</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sangam_literature" title="Sangam literature">Sangam literature</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 600&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>&nbsp;– c.<span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 300&nbsp;<span title="Before Common Era">BCE</span></span>) consisting of 2,381 poems, composed by 473 poets, is the earliest work.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZvelebil199712_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZvelebil199712-446">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHart1975_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHart1975-447">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamanujan1985ix–x_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamanujan1985ix–x-448">[429]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[430]</a></sup> From the 14th to the 18th centuries, India's literary traditions went through a period of drastic change because of the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">devotional poets</a> like <a href="/wiki/Kabir" title="Kabir">Kabīr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tulsidas" title="Tulsidas">Tulsīdās</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guru_Nanak" title="Guru Nanak">Guru Nānak</a>. This period was characterised by a varied and wide spectrum of thought and expression; as a consequence, medieval Indian literary works differed significantly from classical traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDas2005_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDas2005-450">[431]</a></sup> In the 19th century, Indian writers took a new interest in social questions and psychological descriptions. In the 20th century, Indian literature was influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Works_of_Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Works of Rabindranath Tagore">works</a> of the Bengali poet, author and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Rabindranath_Tagore" title="Rabindranath Tagore">Rabindranath Tagore</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDatta2006_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDatta2006-451">[432]</a></sup> who was a recipient of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts_and_media">Performing arts and media</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_India" title="Music of India">Music of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_India" title="Dance in India">Dance in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Cinema of India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Television_in_India" title="Television in India">Television in India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:172px;max-width:172px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:237px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/168px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg" decoding="async" width="168" height="238" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/252px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg/336px-Kuchipudi_Performer_DS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1700" data-file-height="2405"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">India's <a href="/wiki/Sangeet_Natak_Akademi" title="Sangeet Natak Akademi">National Academy of Performance Arts</a> has recognised eight Indian dance styles to be <i>classical</i>.  One such is <a href="/wiki/Kuchipudi" title="Kuchipudi">Kuchipudi</a> shown here.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Indian music ranges over various traditions and regional styles. <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Classical music</a> encompasses two genres and their various folk offshoots: the northern <a href="/wiki/Hindustani_classical_music" title="Hindustani classical music">Hindustani</a> and the southern <a href="/wiki/Carnatic_music" title="Carnatic music">Carnatic</a> schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMasseyMassey1998_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMasseyMassey1998-452">[433]</a></sup> Regionalised popular forms include <a href="/wiki/Filmi" title="Filmi">filmi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_folk_music" title="Indian folk music">folk music</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> tradition of the <i><a href="/wiki/Baul" title="Baul">bauls</a></i> is a well-known form of the latter. <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_India" title="Dance in India">Indian dance</a> also features diverse folk and classical forms. Among the better-known <a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_folk_dances" title="List of Indian folk dances">folk dances</a> are: <i><a href="/wiki/Bhangra_(dance)" title="Bhangra (dance)">bhangra</a></i> of Punjab, <i><a href="/wiki/Bihu_dance" title="Bihu dance">bihu</a></i> of Assam, <i><a href="/wiki/Jhumair" title="Jhumair">Jhumair</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chhau_dance" title="Chhau dance">chhau</a></i> of Jharkhand, Odisha and West Bengal, <i><a href="/wiki/Garba_(dance)" title="Garba (dance)">garba</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dandiya_Raas" title="Dandiya Raas">dandiya</a></i> of Gujarat, <i><a href="/wiki/Ghoomar" title="Ghoomar">ghoomar</a></i> of Rajasthan, and <i><a href="/wiki/Lavani" title="Lavani">lavani</a></i> of Maharashtra. Eight dance forms, many with narrative forms and mythological elements, have been accorded <a href="/wiki/Classical_Indian_dance" class="mw-redirect" title="Classical Indian dance">classical dance status</a> by India's <a href="/wiki/Sangeet_Natak_Akademi" title="Sangeet Natak Akademi">National Academy of Music, Dance, and Drama</a>. These are: <i><a href="/wiki/Bharata_Natyam" class="mw-redirect" title="Bharata Natyam">bharatanatyam</a></i> of the state of Tamil Nadu, <i><a href="/wiki/Kathak" title="Kathak">kathak</a></i> of Uttar Pradesh, <i><a href="/wiki/Kathakali" title="Kathakali">kathakali</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mohiniyattam" title="Mohiniyattam">mohiniyattam</a></i> of Kerala, <i><a href="/wiki/Kuchipudi" title="Kuchipudi">kuchipudi</a></i> of Andhra Pradesh, <i><a href="/wiki/Manipuri_dance" title="Manipuri dance">manipuri</a></i> of Manipur, <i><a href="/wiki/Odissi" title="Odissi">odissi</a></i> of Odisha, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Sattriya" title="Sattriya">sattriya</a></i> of Assam.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[434]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Theatre_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Theatre in India">Theatre in India</a> melds music, dance, and improvised or written dialogue.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELal200423,_30,_235_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELal200423,_30,_235-454">[435]</a></sup> Often based on Hindu mythology, but also borrowing from medieval romances or social and political events, Indian theatre includes: the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhavai" title="Bhavai">bhavai</a></i> of Gujarat, the <i><a href="/wiki/Jatra_(Bengal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jatra (Bengal)">jatra</a></i> of West Bengal, the <i><a href="/wiki/Nautanki" title="Nautanki">nautanki</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Ramlila" title="Ramlila">ramlila</a></i> of North India, <i><a href="/wiki/Tamasha" title="Tamasha">tamasha</a></i> of Maharashtra, <i><a href="/wiki/Burrakatha" class="mw-redirect" title="Burrakatha">burrakatha</a></i> of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, <i><a href="/wiki/Terukkuttu" title="Terukkuttu">terukkuttu</a></i> of Tamil Nadu, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Yakshagana" title="Yakshagana">yakshagana</a></i> of Karnataka.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaranth200226_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranth200226-455">[436]</a></sup> India has a theatre training institute the <a href="/wiki/National_School_of_Drama" title="National School of Drama">National School of Drama</a> (NSD) that is situated at <a href="/wiki/New_Delhi" title="New Delhi">New Delhi</a>. It is an autonomous organisation under the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(India)" title="Ministry of Culture (India)">Ministry of culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[437]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_India" title="Cinema of India">Indian film industry</a> produces the world's most-watched cinema.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDissanayakeGokulsing2004_457-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDissanayakeGokulsing2004-457">[438]</a></sup> Established regional cinematic traditions exist in the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Assam" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Assam">Assamese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_West_Bengal" title="Cinema of West Bengal">Bengali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bhojpuri_cinema" title="Bhojpuri cinema">Bhojpuri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bollywood" class="mw-redirect" title="Bollywood">Hindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Karnataka" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Karnataka">Kannada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malayalam_cinema" title="Malayalam cinema">Malayalam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Punjab" class="mw-redirect" title="Cinema of Punjab">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_cinema" title="Gujarati cinema">Gujarati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marathi_cinema" title="Marathi cinema">Marathi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Odisha" title="Cinema of Odisha">Odia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_cinema" title="Tamil cinema">Tamil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Telugu_cinema" title="Telugu cinema">Telugu</a> languages.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERajadhyakshaWillemen1999652_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERajadhyakshaWillemen1999652-458">[439]</a></sup> The Hindi language film industry (<i>Bollywood</i>) is the largest sector representing 43% of box office revenue, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_South_India" title="Cinema of South India">South Indian</a> Telugu and Tamil film industries which represent 36% combined.<sup id="cite_ref-deloitte_459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deloitte-459">[440]</a></sup>
</p><p>Television broadcasting began in India in 1959 as a state-run medium of communication and expanded slowly for more than two decades.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayan201366–67_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayan201366–67-460">[441]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKaminskyLong2011684–692_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaminskyLong2011684–692-461">[442]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Doordarshan" title="Doordarshan">state monopoly</a> on television broadcast ended in the 1990s. Since then, satellite channels have increasingly shaped the popular culture of Indian society.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMehta20081–10_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMehta20081–10-462">[443]</a></sup> Today, television is the most penetrative media in India; industry estimates indicate that as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there are over 554 million TV consumers, 462&nbsp;million with satellite or cable connections compared to other forms of mass media such as the press (350&nbsp;million), radio (156&nbsp;million) or internet (37&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHansa_Research2012_463-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHansa_Research2012-463">[444]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Society">Society</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:139px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar,_Kashmir.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/208px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/312px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg/416px-Muslims_praying_in_mosque_in_Srinagar%2C_Kashmir.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="685"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Muslims offer <i><a href="/wiki/Salah" title="Salah">namaz</a></i> at a mosque in <a href="/wiki/Srinagar" title="Srinagar">Srinagar</a>, Jammu and Kashmir.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Traditional Indian society is sometimes defined by social hierarchy. The <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">Indian caste system</a> embodies much of the social stratification and many of the social restrictions found on the Indian subcontinent. Social classes are defined by thousands of <a href="/wiki/Endogamous" class="mw-redirect" title="Endogamous">endogamous</a> hereditary groups, often termed as <i><a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti" title="Jāti">jātis</a></i>, or "castes".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchwartzberg2011_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchwartzberg2011-464">[445]</a></sup> India abolished <a href="/wiki/Untouchability" title="Untouchability">untouchability</a> in 1950 with the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_India" title="Constitution of India">constitution</a> and has since enacted other anti-discriminatory laws and social welfare initiatives.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Family_values" title="Family values">Family values</a> are important in the Indian tradition, and multi-generational <a href="/wiki/Patrilineal" class="mw-redirect" title="Patrilineal">patrilineal</a> <a href="/wiki/Joint_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Joint family">joint families</a> have been the norm in India, though <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_family" title="Nuclear family">nuclear families</a> are becoming common in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakar2007_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakar2007-465">[446]</a></sup> An overwhelming majority of Indians, with their consent, have <a href="/wiki/Arranged_marriage_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Arranged marriage in the Indian subcontinent">their marriages arranged</a> by their parents or other family elders.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMedora2003_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMedora2003-466">[447]</a></sup> Marriage is thought to be for life,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMedora2003_466-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMedora2003-466">[447]</a></sup> and the divorce rate is extremely low,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRamdas2005111_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRamdas2005111-467">[448]</a></sup> with less than one in a thousand marriages ending in divorce.<sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[449]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage" title="Child marriage">Child marriages</a> are common, especially in rural areas; many women wed before reaching 18, which is their legal marriageable age.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECullen-Dupont200996_469-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECullen-Dupont200996-469">[450]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Female_infanticide_in_India" title="Female infanticide in India">Female infanticide in India</a>, and lately <a href="/wiki/Female_foeticide_in_India" title="Female foeticide in India">female foeticide</a>, have created skewed gender ratios; the number of <a href="/wiki/Missing_women" title="Missing women">missing women</a> in the country quadrupled from 15 million to 63&nbsp;million in the 50-year period ending in 2014, faster than the population growth during the same period, and constituting 20 percent of India's female electorate.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Hindu_November_17_2019c_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Hindu_November_17_2019c-470">[451]</a></sup> According to an Indian government study, an additional 21 million girls are unwanted and do not receive adequate care.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_November_17_2019c_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian_November_17_2019c-471">[452]</a></sup> Despite a government ban on sex-selective foeticide, the practice remains commonplace in India, the result of a preference for boys in a patriarchal society.<sup id="cite_ref-Foreign_Policy_November_17_2019c_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foreign_Policy_November_17_2019c-472">[453]</a></sup> The payment of <a href="/wiki/Dowry_system_in_India" title="Dowry system in India">dowry</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Dowry_law_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Dowry law in India">illegal</a>, remains widespread across class lines.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[454]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dowry_deaths" class="mw-redirect" title="Dowry deaths">Deaths resulting from dowry</a>, mostly from <a href="/wiki/Bride_burning" title="Bride burning">bride burning</a>, are on the rise, despite stringent anti-dowry laws.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_India" title="Public holidays in India">Indian festivals</a> are religious in origin. The best known include <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi" title="Ganesh Chaturthi">Ganesh Chaturthi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_Pongal" class="mw-redirect" title="Thai Pongal">Thai Pongal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_ul-Fitr" class="mw-redirect" title="Eid ul-Fitr">Eid ul-Fitr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bakr-Id" class="mw-redirect" title="Bakr-Id">Bakr-Id</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christmas_worldwide#India" class="mw-redirect" title="Christmas worldwide">Christmas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vaisakhi" title="Vaisakhi">Vaisakhi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[456]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_India" title="Education in India">Education in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Literacy_in_India" title="Literacy in India">Literacy in India</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of education in the Indian subcontinent">History of education in the Indian subcontinent</a></div>
<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_(3384824242).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg/220px-47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg/330px-47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg/440px-47_Raika_School_-_eating_together_%283384824242%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a><figcaption>Children awaiting school lunch in Rayka (also Raika), a village in rural Gujarat. The salutation <i><a href="/wiki/Jai_Bhim" title="Jai Bhim">Jai Bhim</a></i> written on the blackboard honours the jurist, social reformer, and <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">Dalit</a> leader <a href="/wiki/B._R._Ambedkar" title="B. R. Ambedkar">B. R. Ambedkar</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the 2011 census, about 73% of the population was literate, with 81% for men and 65% for women. This compares to 1981 when the respective rates were 41%, 53% and 29%. In 1951 the rates were 18%, 27% and 9%. In 1921 the rates 7%, 12% and 2%. In 1891 they were 5%, 9% and 1%,<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[459]</a></sup> According to Latika Chaudhary, in 1911 there were under three primary schools for every ten villages. Statistically, more caste and religious diversity reduced private spending. Primary schools taught literacy, so local diversity limited its growth.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[460]</a></sup>
</p><p>The education system of India is the world's second-largest.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[461]</a></sup> India has over 900 universities, 40,000 colleges<sup id="cite_ref-highered1_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-highered1-481">[462]</a></sup> and 1.5&nbsp;million schools.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[463]</a></sup> In India's higher education system, a significant number of seats are reserved under <a href="/wiki/Reservation_in_India" title="Reservation in India">affirmative action</a> policies for the historically disadvantaged. In recent decades India's improved education system is often cited as one of the main contributors to its <a href="/wiki/Economic_development_in_India" title="Economic development in India">economic development</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sify_483-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sify-483">[464]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[465]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Clothing">Clothing</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Clothing_in_India" title="Clothing in India">Clothing in India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:352px;max-width:352px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:234px;max-width:234px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:174px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:India_School.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/232px-India_School.jpg" decoding="async" width="232" height="174" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/348px-India_School.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/India_School.jpg/464px-India_School.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Women in <a href="/wiki/Sari" title="Sari">sari</a> at an adult literacy class in <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:114px;max-width:114px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:174px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Water_pump,_Varanasi_(15563170660)_Cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/112px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="112" height="174" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/168px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg/224px-Water_pump%2C_Varanasi_%2815563170660%29_Cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="2314"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">A man in <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a> and wearing a woollen shawl, in <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>From ancient times until the advent of the modern, the most widely worn traditional dress in India was <a href="/wiki/Draped_garment" title="Draped garment">draped</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-485">[466]</a></sup> For women it took the form of a <a href="/wiki/Sari" title="Sari">sari</a>, a single piece of cloth many yards long.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_485-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-485">[466]</a></sup> The sari was traditionally wrapped around the lower body and the shoulder.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_485-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-485">[466]</a></sup> In its modern form, it is combined with an underskirt, or Indian <a href="/wiki/Petticoat#Asian_petticoats" title="Petticoat">petticoat</a>, and tucked in the waist band for more secure fastening. It is also commonly worn with an Indian <a href="/wiki/Blouse" title="Blouse">blouse</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Choli" title="Choli">choli</a>, which serves as the primary upper-body garment, the sari's end—passing over the shoulder—serving to cover the midriff and obscure the upper body's contours.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26_485-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-485">[466]</a></sup> For men, a similar but shorter length of cloth, the <a href="/wiki/Dhoti" title="Dhoti">dhoti</a>, has served as a lower-body garment.<sup id="cite_ref-Tarlo1996-26-28_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarlo1996-26-28-486">[467]</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:172px;max-width:172px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:210px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/168px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg" decoding="async" width="168" height="210" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/252px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg/336px-Strolling_Shoppers_in_Paltan_Bazaar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1456" data-file-height="1821"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Women (from left to right) in <a href="/wiki/Churidar" title="Churidar">churidars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Kameez">kameez</a> (with back to the camera), jeans and sweater, and pink <a href="/wiki/Shalwar_kameez" title="Shalwar kameez">shalwar kameez</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The use of stitched clothes became widespread after Muslim rule was established at first by the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_sultanate" class="mw-redirect" title="Delhi sultanate">Delhi sultanate</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1300 CE</span>) and then continued by the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1525 CE</span>).<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-487">[468]</a></sup> Among the garments introduced during this time and still commonly worn are: the <a href="/wiki/Shalwar" class="mw-redirect" title="Shalwar">shalwars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pyjama" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyjama">pyjamas</a>, both styles of trousers, and the tunics <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kameez" class="mw-redirect" title="Kameez">kameez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_487-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-487">[468]</a></sup> In southern India, the traditional draped garments were to see much longer continuous use.<sup id="cite_ref-Rahman-Alkazi2002_487-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rahman-Alkazi2002-487">[468]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shalwars are atypically wide at the waist but narrow to a cuffed bottom. They are held up by a drawstring, which causes them to become pleated around the waist.<sup id="cite_ref-StevensonWaite2011_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StevensonWaite2011-488">[469]</a></sup> The pants can be wide and baggy, or they can be cut quite narrow, on the <a href="/wiki/Grain_(textile)#Bias" title="Grain (textile)">bias</a>, in which case they are called <a href="/wiki/Churidar" title="Churidar">churidars</a>. When they are ordinarily wide at the waist and their bottoms are hemmed but not cuffed, they are called pyjamas. The kameez is a long shirt or tunic,<sup id="cite_ref-StevensonWaite2011-b_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-StevensonWaite2011-b-489">[470]</a></sup> its side seams left open below the waist-line.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[471]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kurta" title="Kurta">kurta</a> is traditionally collarless and made of cotton or silk; it is worn plain or with embroidered decoration, such as <a href="/wiki/Chikan_(embroidery)" title="Chikan (embroidery)">chikan</a>; and typically falls to either just above or just below the wearer's knees.<sup id="cite_ref-Shukla2015_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shukla2015-491">[472]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the last 50 years, fashions have changed a great deal in India. Increasingly, in urban northern India, the sari is no longer the apparel of everyday wear, though they remain popular on formal occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_492-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-492">[473]</a></sup> The traditional shalwar kameez is rarely worn by younger urban women, who favour churidars or jeans.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_492-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-492">[473]</a></sup> In white-collar office settings, ubiquitous air conditioning allows men to wear sports jackets year-round.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_492-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-492">[473]</a></sup> For weddings and formal occasions, men in the middle- and upper classes often wear <a href="/wiki/Bandgala" class="mw-redirect" title="Bandgala">bandgala</a>, or short <a href="/wiki/Nehru_jackets" class="mw-redirect" title="Nehru jackets">Nehru jackets</a>, with pants, with the groom and his <a href="/wiki/Groomsmen" class="mw-redirect" title="Groomsmen">groomsmen</a> sporting <a href="/wiki/Sherwani" title="Sherwani">sherwanis</a> and churidars.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_492-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-492">[473]</a></sup> The dhoti, once the universal garment of Hindu males, the wearing of which in the homespun and handwoven <a href="/wiki/Khadi" title="Khadi">khadi</a> allowed Gandhi to bring Indian nationalism to the millions,<sup id="cite_ref-BruzziGibson2013_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BruzziGibson2013-493">[474]</a></sup>
is seldom seen in the cities.<sup id="cite_ref-Dwyer2014_492-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dwyer2014-492">[473]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:172px;max-width:172px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:103px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/168px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="168" height="104" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/252px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg/336px-South_Indian_Thali_Cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2567" data-file-height="1583"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">South Indian vegetarian <a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a>, or platter</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:132px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Odia_Mutton_Curry_(Mansha_Tarkari)_Rotated.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/168px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg" decoding="async" width="168" height="132" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/252px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg/336px-Odia_Mutton_Curry_%28Mansha_Tarkari%29_Rotated.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1229" data-file-height="966"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Railway <a href="/wiki/Mutton_curry" title="Mutton curry">mutton curry</a> from <a href="/wiki/Odisha" title="Odisha">Odisha</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The foundation of a typical Indian meal is a cereal cooked in a plain fashion and complemented with flavourful savoury dishes.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-494">[475]</a></sup> The cooked cereal could be steamed rice; <a href="/wiki/Chapati" title="Chapati">chapati</a>, a thin unleavened bread made from wheat flour, or occasionally cornmeal, and griddle-cooked dry;<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p161_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p161-495">[476]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Idli" title="Idli">idli</a>, a steamed breakfast cake, or <a href="/wiki/Dosa_(food)" title="Dosa (food)">dosa</a>, a griddled pancake, both leavened and made from a batter of rice- and <a href="/wiki/Vigna_mungo" title="Vigna mungo">gram</a> meal.<sup id="cite_ref-tamang-yeast-idlidosa_496-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tamang-yeast-idlidosa-496">[477]</a></sup> The savoury dishes might include <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pulses" class="mw-redirect" title="Pulses">pulses</a> and vegetables commonly spiced with <a href="/wiki/Ginger_root" class="mw-redirect" title="Ginger root">ginger</a> and <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a>, but also with a combination of spices that may include <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turmeric" title="Turmeric">turmeric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinnamon" title="Cinnamon">cinnamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardamon" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardamon">cardamon</a> and others as informed by culinary conventions.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_494-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-494">[475]</a></sup> They might also include poultry, fish, or meat dishes. In some instances, the ingredients might be mixed during the process of cooking.<sup id="cite_ref-jhala-princely-biryani_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jhala-princely-biryani-497">[478]</a></sup>
</p><p>A platter, or <a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a>, used for eating usually has a central place reserved for the cooked cereal, and peripheral ones for the flavourful accompaniments, which are often served in small bowls. The cereal and its accompaniments are eaten simultaneously rather than a piecemeal manner. This is accomplished by mixing—for example of rice and lentils—or folding, wrapping, scooping or dipping—such as chapati and cooked vegetables or lentils.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p409_494-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p409-494">[475]</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><span class="mw-tmh-player video"><video id="mwe_player_2_placeholder" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm/180px--Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm.jpg" preload="none" class="mw-file-element" width="180" height="320" data-durationhint="14" data-mwtitle="Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm" playsinline="" disabled="disabled" tabindex="-1" style="aspect-ratio: 180 / 320;"></video><a class="mw-tmh-play" href="/wiki/File:Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm" title="Play video" role="button"><span class="mw-tmh-play-icon"></span></a><span class="mw-tmh-duration mw-tmh-label"><span class="sr-only">Duration: 14 seconds.</span><span aria-hidden="true">0:14</span></span></span></span><a href="/wiki/File:Making_Khameeri_Roti_in_Tandoor_in_Turkman_Gate_Old_Delhi.webm" class="mw-file-magnify"></a><figcaption>A tandoor chef in the <a href="/wiki/Turkman_Gate" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkman Gate">Turkman Gate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_Delhi" title="Old Delhi">Old Delhi</a>, makes Khameeri <a href="/wiki/Roti" title="Roti">roti</a> (a Muslim-influenced style of <a href="/wiki/Bread#Leavening" title="Bread">leavened bread</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Panjabi1995_498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Panjabi1995-498">[479]</a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>India has distinctive vegetarian cuisines, each a feature of the geographical and cultural histories of its adherents.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-499">[480]</a></sup> The appearance of <i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i>, or the avoidance of violence toward all forms of life in many religious orders early in Indian history, especially <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishadic Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, is thought to have contributed to the predominance of vegetarianism among a large segment of India's Hindu population, especially in southern India, Gujarat, the <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>-speaking belt of north-central India, as well as among Jains.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_499-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-499">[480]</a></sup> Although meat is eaten widely in India, the proportional consumption of meat in the overall diet is low.<sup id="cite_ref-SahakianSaloma2016-50_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SahakianSaloma2016-50-500">[481]</a></sup> Unlike China, which has increased its per capita meat consumption substantially in its years of increased economic growth, in India the strong dietary traditions have contributed to dairy, rather than meat, becoming the preferred form of animal protein consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-OECDNations2018_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECDNations2018-501">[482]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most significant import of cooking techniques into India during the last millennium occurred during the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>. Dishes such as the <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoger2000_502-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoger2000-502">[483]</a></sup> developed in the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_caliphate" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbasid caliphate">Abbasid caliphate</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-sengupta-74_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sengupta-74-503">[484]</a></sup> and cooking techniques such as the marinating of meat in yogurt, spread into northern India from regions to its northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-504">[485]</a></sup> To the simple yogurt marinade of Persia, onions, garlic, almonds, and spices began to be added in India.<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_504-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-504">[485]</a></sup> Rice was partially cooked and layered alternately with the sauteed meat, the pot sealed tightly, and slow cooked according to another Persian cooking technique, to produce what has today become the Indian <a href="/wiki/Biryani" title="Biryani">biryani</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CollinghamCollingham2007_504-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CollinghamCollingham2007-504">[485]</a></sup> a feature of festive dining in many parts of India.<sup id="cite_ref-nandy2004_505-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nandy2004-505">[486]</a></sup> In the food served in Indian restaurants worldwide the diversity of Indian food has been partially concealed by the dominance of <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_cuisine" title="Punjabi cuisine">Punjabi cuisine</a>. The popularity of <a href="/wiki/Tandoori_chicken" title="Tandoori chicken">tandoori chicken</a>—cooked in the <a href="/wiki/Tandoor" title="Tandoor">tandoor</a> oven, which had traditionally been used for baking bread in the rural Punjab and the Delhi region, especially among Muslims, but which is originally from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>—dates to the 1950s, and was caused in large part by an entrepreneurial response among people from the Punjab who had been displaced by the 1947 <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition of India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Davidson2014-p410_499-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davidson2014-p410-499">[480]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_and_recreation">Sports and recreation</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_India" title="Sport in India">Sport in India</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:210px;max-width:210px"><div class="thumbimage" style="border:none;;height:138px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle,_Jaura,_Inde.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/208px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg" decoding="async" width="208" height="139" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/312px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg/416px-Filles_jouant_%C3%A0_la_marelle%2C_Jaura%2C_Inde.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption">Girls play <a href="/wiki/Hopscotch" title="Hopscotch">hopscotch</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jaora" title="Jaora">Jaora</a>, Madhya Pradesh.  Hopscotch has been commonly played by girls in rural India.<sup id="cite_ref-SrinivasanJermyn2001_506-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SrinivasanJermyn2001-506">[487]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Several <a href="/wiki/Traditional_games_of_India" title="Traditional games of India">traditional indigenous sports</a> such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kabaddi" title="Kabaddi">kabaddi</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kho_kho" title="Kho kho">kho kho</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Pehlwani" title="Pehlwani">pehlwani</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gilli-danda" class="mw-redirect" title="Gilli-danda">gilli-danda</a></i>, and also <a href="/wiki/Indian_martial_arts" title="Indian martial arts">martial arts</a> such as <i><a href="/wiki/Kalarippayattu" class="mw-redirect" title="Kalarippayattu">Kalarippayattu</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Marma_adi" class="mw-redirect" title="Marma adi">marma adi</a></i>, remain popular. <a href="/wiki/Chess_in_India" title="Chess in India">Chess</a> is commonly held to have <a href="/wiki/History_of_chess#India" title="History of chess">originated in India</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/Chaturanga" title="Chaturanga">chaturaṅga</a></i>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWolpert20032_507-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert20032-507">[488]</a></sup> in recent years, there has been a rise in the number of Indian <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">grandmasters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_b_508-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_b-508">[489]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Viswanathan_Anand" title="Viswanathan Anand">Viswanathan Anand</a> became the <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2007" title="World Chess Championship 2007">Chess World Champion</a> in 2007 and held the title until 2013. He also won the <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup" title="Chess World Cup">Chess World Cup</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2000" title="Chess World Cup 2000">2000</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2002" title="Chess World Cup 2002">2002</a>. In 2023, 18-year-old <a href="/wiki/R_Praggnanandhaa" title="R Praggnanandhaa">R Praggnanandhaa</a> finished as runner-up in the <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2023" title="Chess World Cup 2023">Chess World Cup 2023</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[490]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Parcheesi" title="Parcheesi">Parcheesi</a> is derived from <i><a href="/wiki/Pachisi" title="Pachisi">Pachisi</a></i>, another traditional Indian pastime, which in early modern times was played on a giant marble court by <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Akbar_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Akbar the Great">Akbar the Great</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBinmore200798_510-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBinmore200798-510">[491]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Tabletop_game" title="Tabletop game">tabletop game</a> <a href="/wiki/Carrom" title="Carrom">carrom</a>, which originated in India, is also very popular.<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">[492]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cricket_in_India" title="Cricket in India">Cricket</a> is the most popular sport in India.<sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">[493]</a></sup> Major domestic leagues include the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Premier_League" title="Indian Premier League">Indian Premier League</a>. Professional leagues in other sports include the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Super_League" title="Indian Super League">Indian Super League</a> (<a href="/wiki/Soccer" class="mw-redirect" title="Soccer">football</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Pro_Kabaddi_League" title="Pro Kabaddi League">Pro Kabaddi</a> league.<sup id="cite_ref-513" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-513">[494]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-514" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-514">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/440px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg" decoding="async" width="440" height="115" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/660px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg/880px-Sachin_Tendulkar_about_to_score_14000th_run_in_test_cricket.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2650" data-file-height="690"></a><figcaption>Indian <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricketer</a> <a href="/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar" title="Sachin Tendulkar">Sachin Tendulkar</a> about to score a record 14,000 runs in <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test cricket</a> while playing against Australia in <a href="/wiki/Bangalore" title="Bangalore">Bangalore</a>, 2010</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/India_national_cricket_team" title="India national cricket team">India</a> has won two <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cups</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1983_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1983 Cricket World Cup">1983 edition</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2011 Cricket World Cup">2011 edition</a>, as well as becoming the inaugural <a href="/wiki/T20_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="T20 World Cup">T20 World Cup</a> Champions in <a href="/wiki/2007_ICC_World_Twenty20" title="2007 ICC World Twenty20">2007</a>. India has also won the <a href="/wiki/ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="ICC Champions Trophy">Champions Trophy</a> twice, in <a href="/wiki/2002_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2002 ICC Champions Trophy">2002</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2013 ICC Champions Trophy">2013</a>. The only edition of the <a href="/wiki/World_Championship_of_Cricket" title="World Championship of Cricket">World Championship of Cricket</a> was won by India in <a href="/wiki/1985_World_Championship_of_Cricket_final" title="1985 World Championship of Cricket final">1985</a>.
</p><p>India also has eight field hockey gold medals in the <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Field hockey at the Summer Olympics">summer olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">[497]</a></sup>
The improved results garnered by the <a href="/wiki/India_Davis_Cup_team" title="India Davis Cup team">Indian Davis Cup team</a> and other tennis players in the early 2010s have made tennis increasingly popular in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuttermanSharma2009_517-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuttermanSharma2009-517">[498]</a></sup> India has a comparatively strong presence in shooting sports, and has won several medals at the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympics</a>, the <a href="/wiki/ISSF_World_Shooting_Championships" title="ISSF World Shooting Championships">World Shooting Championships</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">Commonwealth Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECommonwealth_Games_2010_518-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECommonwealth_Games_2010-518">[499]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECyriac2010_519-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECyriac2010-519">[500]</a></sup> Other sports in which Indians have succeeded internationally include <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_a_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2010_a-520">[501]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Saina_Nehwal" title="Saina Nehwal">Saina Nehwal</a> and <a href="/wiki/P._V._Sindhu" title="P. V. Sindhu">P. V. Sindhu</a> are two of the top-ranked female badminton players in the world), boxing,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMint_2010_521-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMint_2010-521">[502]</a></sup> and wrestling.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEXavier2010_522-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEXavier2010-522">[503]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Football_in_India" title="Football in India">Football</a> is popular in <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">West Bengal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamil_Nadu" title="Tamil Nadu">Tamil Nadu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kerala" title="Kerala">Kerala</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sister_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Seven Sister States">north-eastern states</a>. India has traditionally been the dominant country at the <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_Games" title="South Asian Games">South Asian Games</a>. An example of this dominance is the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_South_Asian_Games" title="Basketball at the South Asian Games">basketball competition</a>, where the <a href="/wiki/India_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="India national basketball team">Indian team</a> won four out of five tournaments to date.<sup id="cite_ref-523" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-523">[504]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMajumdarBandyopadhyay20061–5_524-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMajumdarBandyopadhyay20061–5-524">[505]</a></sup>
</p><p>India has hosted or co-hosted several international sporting events: the <a href="/wiki/1951_Asian_Games" title="1951 Asian Games">1951</a> and <a href="/wiki/1982_Asian_Games" title="1982 Asian Games">1982 Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1987 Cricket World Cup">1987</a>, <a href="/wiki/1996_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1996 Cricket World Cup">1996</a>, <a href="/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2011 Cricket World Cup">2011</a> and <a href="/wiki/2023_ICC_Men%27s_Cricket_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2023 ICC Men's Cricket World Cup">2023 ICC Men's Cricket World Cup</a> tournaments (and is also scheduled to host it in <a href="/wiki/2031_Cricket_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2031 Cricket World Cup">2031</a>); the <a href="/wiki/1978_Women%27s_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1978 Women's Cricket World Cup">1978</a>, <a href="/wiki/1997_Women%27s_Cricket_World_Cup" title="1997 Women's Cricket World Cup">1997</a> and <a href="/wiki/2013_Women%27s_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2013 Women's Cricket World Cup">2013 ICC Women's Cricket World Cup</a> tournaments (and is also scheduled to host it in <a href="/wiki/2025_Women%27s_Cricket_World_Cup" title="2025 Women's Cricket World Cup">2025</a>); the <a href="/wiki/1987_South_Asian_Games" title="1987 South Asian Games">1987</a>, <a href="/wiki/1995_South_Asian_Games" title="1995 South Asian Games">1985</a> and <a href="/wiki/2016_South_Asian_Games" title="2016 South Asian Games">2016 South Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/1990-91_Asia_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="1990-91 Asia Cup">1990-91 Men's Asia Cup</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2002" title="Chess World Cup 2002">2002 Chess World Cup</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2003_Afro-Asian_Games" title="2003 Afro-Asian Games">2003 Afro-Asian Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2006_ICC_Champions_Trophy" title="2006 ICC Champions Trophy">2006 ICC Cricket Champion's Trophy</a> (and is also scheduled to host it in <a href="/wiki/2029_ICC_Champions_Trophy" class="mw-redirect" title="2029 ICC Champions Trophy">2029</a>); the <a href="/wiki/2006_Women%27s_Asia_Cup" title="2006 Women's Asia Cup">2006 Women's Asia Cup</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2009_BWF_World_Championships" title="2009 BWF World Championships">2009 World Badminton Championships</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2010_Men%27s_Hockey_World_Cup" title="2010 Men's Hockey World Cup">2010 Hockey World Cup</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2010_Commonwealth_Games" title="2010 Commonwealth Games">2010 Commonwealth Games</a>; the <a href="/wiki/2016_T20_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 T20 World Cup">2016 ICC Men's Cricket T20 World Cup</a> (and is also scheduled to host it in <a href="/wiki/2026_ICC_Men%27s_T20_World_Cup" title="2026 ICC Men's T20 World Cup">2026</a>); the <a href="/wiki/2016_ICC_Women%27s_World_Twenty20" title="2016 ICC Women's World Twenty20">2016 ICC Women's Cricket T20 World Cup</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_U-17_World_Cup" title="2017 FIFA U-17 World Cup">2017 FIFA U-17 World Cup</a>. Major international sporting events held annually in India include the <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra_Open" title="Maharashtra Open">Maharashtra Open</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mumbai_Marathon" title="Mumbai Marathon">Mumbai Marathon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Half_Marathon" title="Delhi Half Marathon">Delhi Half Marathon</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Masters" title="Indian Masters">Indian Masters</a>. The first Formula 1 <a href="/wiki/Indian_Grand_Prix" title="Indian Grand Prix">Indian Grand Prix</a> featured in late 2011 but has been discontinued from the F1 season calendar since 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDehejia2011_525-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDehejia2011-525">[506]</a></sup>
</p>
