<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-lower-alpha" style="column-width: 33em;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Originally written in <a href="/wiki/Sadhu_bhasha" title="Sadhu bhasha">Sanskritised Bengali</a> and adopted as the national anthem in its Hindi translation</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"[...] <i>Jana Gana Mana</i> is the National Anthem of India, subject to such alterations in the words as the Government may authorise as occasion arises; and the song <i>Vande Mataram</i>, which has played a historic part in the struggle for Indian freedom, shall be honoured equally with <i>Jana Gana Mana</i> and shall have equal status with it."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstituent_Assembly_of_India1950_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstituent_Assembly_of_India1950-6">[5]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Written in a mixture of Sanskrit and <a href="/wiki/Sadhu_bhasha" title="Sadhu bhasha">Sanskritised Bengali</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to <a href="/wiki/Part_XVII_of_the_Constitution_of_India" title="Part XVII of the Constitution of India">Part XVII of the Constitution of India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_Hindi" class="mw-redirect" title="Standard Hindi">Hindi</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script is the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> of the Union, along with <a href="/wiki/Indian_English" title="Indian English">English</a> as an additional official language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Informatics_Centre2005-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960-9">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-india.gov.in2_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-india.gov.in2-10">[7]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India" title="States and union territories of India">States and union territories</a> can have a different official language of their own other than Hindi or English.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Not all the state-level official languages are in the eighth schedule and not all the scheduled languages are state-level official languages. For example, the <a href="/wiki/Sindhi_language" title="Sindhi language">Sindhi language</a> is an 8th scheduled but not a state-level official language.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Kashmiri_language" title="Kashmiri language">Kashmiri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dogri_language" title="Dogri language">Dogri language</a> are the official languages of <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a> which is currently a <a href="/wiki/Union_territory" title="Union territory">union territory</a> and no longer the <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(state)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (state)">former state</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Different sources give widely differing figures, primarily based on how the terms "language" and "dialect" are defined and grouped. <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a> lists 461 tongues for India (out of 6,912 worldwide), 447 of which are living, while 14 are extinct.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-17">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue2_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue2-18">[12]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The country's exact size is subject to debate because some borders are disputed. The Indian government lists the total area as 3,287,260&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,269,220&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and the total land area as 3,060,500&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,181,700&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi); the United Nations lists the total area as 3,287,263&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,269,219&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and total land area as 2,973,190&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,147,960&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi)."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-21">[14]</a></sup> </span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_India" title="Date and time notation in India">Date and time notation in India</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> also regards <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> as a bordering country, as it considers all of <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> to be part of India. However, this is <a href="/wiki/Kashmir_conflict" title="Kashmir conflict">disputed</a>, and the region bordering Afghanistan is administered by Pakistan. Source: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1133582631">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150317182910/https://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/BMIntro-1011.pdf">"Ministry of Home Affairs (Department of Border Management)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://mha.nic.in/sites/upload_files/mha/files/BMIntro-1011.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 17 March 2015<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 September</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Ministry+of+Home+Affairs+%28Department+of+Border+Management%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fmha.nic.in%2Fsites%2Fupload_files%2Fmha%2Ffiles%2FBMIntro-1011.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-38" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Partly controlled by the unrecognised breakaway state <a href="/wiki/Chinland" title="Chinland">Chinland</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"A Chinese pilgrim also recorded evidence of the caste system as he could observe it. According to this evidence the treatment meted out to untouchables such as the Chandalas was very similar to that which they experienced in later periods. This would contradict assertions that this rigid form of the caste system emerged in India only as a reaction to the Islamic conquest."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493-53">[42]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Shah Jahan eventually sent her body 800&nbsp;km (500 mi) to Agra for burial in the Rauza-i Munauwara ("Illuminated Tomb") – a personal tribute and a stone manifestation of his imperial power. This tomb has been celebrated globally as the Taj Mahal."<sup id="cite_ref-Fisher2018-106_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher2018-106-62">[50]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The northernmost point under Indian control is the disputed <a href="/wiki/Siachen_Glacier" title="Siachen Glacier">Siachen Glacier</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory)" title="Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)">Jammu and Kashmir</a>; however, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_India" title="Government of India">Government of India</a> regards the entire region of the former princely state of Jammu and Kashmir, including the <a href="/wiki/Gilgit-Baltistan" title="Gilgit-Baltistan">Gilgit-Baltistan</a> administered by Pakistan, to be its territory. It therefore assigns the latitude 37° 6′ to its northernmost point.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-217" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A biodiversity hotspot is a <a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">biogeographical</a> region which has more than 1,500 <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plant</a> species, but less than 30% of its primary habitat.<sup id="cite_ref-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018-216">[202]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A forest cover is <i>moderately dense</i> if between 40% and 70% of its area is covered by its tree canopy.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-368"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-368" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 2015, the World Bank raised its international poverty line to $1.90 per day.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[351]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-fnPopulation-382"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-fnPopulation_382-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to estimates by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs" title="United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs">U. N. Population Division</a>, India's population is expected to overtake China's sometime in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[364]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-remaining_religions-396"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-remaining_religions_396-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Besides specific religions, the last two categories in the 2011 Census were "Other religions and persuasions" (0.65%) and "Religion not stated" (0.23%).</span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.thehindu.com/news/national/Hindi-not-a-national-language-Court/article16839525.ece">"Hindi, not a national language: Court"</a>. <i>The Hindu</i>. 25 January 2010.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Hindu&amp;rft.atitle=Hindi%2C+not+a+national+language%3A+Court&amp;rft.date=2010-01-25&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thehindu.com%2Fnews%2Fnational%2FHindi-not-a-national-language-Court%2Farticle16839525.ece&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-langoff-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-langoff_14-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160708012438/https://nclm.nic.in/shared/linkimages/NCLM50thReport.pdf">"50th Report of the Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities in India (July 2012 to June 2013)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-Ethnologue-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ethnologue_17-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFLewis,_M._PaulSimons,_Gary_F.Fennig,_Charles_D.2014" class="citation web cs1">Lewis, M. Paul; Simons, Gary F.; Fennig, Charles D., eds. (2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ethnologue.com/country/IN">"Ethnologue: Languages of the World&nbsp;: India"</a> (17th&nbsp;ed.). Retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 December</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Ethnologue%3A+Languages+of+the+World+%3A+India&amp;rft.place=Dallas%2C+Texas&amp;rft.edition=17th&amp;rft.pub=Ethnologue+by+SIL+International&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ethnologue.com%2Fcountry%2FIN&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>

(identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4654-5528-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4654-5528-4"><bdi>978-1-4654-5528-4</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Complete+Atlas+of+the+World%3A+The+Definitive+View+of+the+Earth&amp;rft.pages=54&amp;rft.edition=3rd&amp;rft.pub=DK+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4654-5528-4&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DO5moCwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA54-IA10&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "Official name: Republic of India";<br>–<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=CQWhAQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA726"><i>Worldwide Government Directory with Intergovernmental Organizations 2013</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/CQ_Press" title="CQ Press">CQ Press</a>, 2013, p.&nbsp;726, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4522-9937-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4522-9937-2"><bdi>978-1-4522-9937-2</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Worldwide+Government+Directory+with+Intergovernmental+Organizations+2013&amp;rft.pages=726&amp;rft.pub=CQ+Press&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4522-9937-2&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DCQWhAQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA726&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span> "India (Republic of India; Bharat Ganarajya)"</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFBiswas2023" class="citation web cs1">Biswas, Soutik (1 May 2023). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-65322706">"Most populous nation: Should India rejoice or panic?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/British_Broadcasting_Corporation" class="mw-redirect" title="British Broadcasting Corporation">British Broadcasting Corporation</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 May</span> 2023</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=BBC+News&amp;rft.atitle=Most+populous+nation%3A+Should+India+rejoice+or+panic%3F&amp;rft.date=2023-05-01&amp;rft.aulast=Biswas&amp;rft.aufirst=Soutik&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2Fnews%2Fworld-asia-india-65322706&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.un.org/development/desa/pd/sites/www.un.org.development.desa.pd/files/wpp2022_summary_of_results.pdf"><i>World Population Prospects 2022: Summary of Results</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. New York: United Nations Department of Social and Economic Affairs. 2022. pp.&nbsp;i.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=World+Population+Prospects+2022%3A+Summary+of+Results&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=i&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations+Department+of+Social+and+Economic+Affairs&amp;rft.date=2022&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fdevelopment%2Fdesa%2Fpd%2Fsites%2Fwww.un.org.development.desa.pd%2Ffiles%2Fwpp2022_summary_of_results.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2012327-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2012327_34-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2012">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2012</a>, p.&nbsp;327: "Even though much remains to be done, especially in regard to eradicating poverty and securing effective structures of governance, India's achievements since independence in sustaining freedom and democracy have been singular among the world's new nations."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-stein-arnold-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-stein-arnold_35-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFStein2012" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Burton_Stein" title="Burton Stein">Stein, Burton</a> (2012), <a href="/wiki/David_Arnold_(historian)" title="David Arnold (historian)">Arnold, David</a> (ed.), <i>A History of India</i>, The Blackwell History of the World Series (2&nbsp;ed.), Wiley-Blackwell, <q>One of these is the idea of India as 'the world's largest democracy', but a democracy forged less by the creation of representative institutions and expanding electorate under British rule than by the endeavours of India's founding fathers – Gandhi, Nehru, Patel and Ambedkar – and the labours of the Constituent Assembly between 1946 and 1949, embodied in the Indian constitution of 1950. This democratic order, reinforced by the regular holding of nationwide elections and polling for the state assemblies, has, it can be argued, consistently underpinned a fundamentally democratic state structure – despite the anomaly of the Emergency and the apparent durability of the Gandhi-Nehru dynasty.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+India&amp;rft.series=The+Blackwell+History+of+the+World+Series&amp;rft.edition=2&amp;rft.pub=Wiley-Blackwell&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.aulast=Stein&amp;rft.aufirst=Burton&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher2018184–185-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisher2018184–185_36-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;184–185: "Since 1947, India's internal disputes over its national identity, while periodically bitter and occasionally punctuated by violence, have been largely managed with remarkable and sustained commitment to national unity and democracy."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-PetragliaAllchin_39-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPetragliaAllchin2007">Petraglia &amp; Allchin 2007</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Qm9GfjNlnRwC&amp;pg=PA10">10</a>, "Y-Chromosome and Mt-DNA data support the colonization of South Asia by modern humans originating in Africa. ... Coalescence dates for most non-European populations average to between 73–55 ka."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018p1-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018p1_40-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018p1_40-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA1">1</a>, "Modern human beings—<i>Homo sapiens</i>—originated in Africa. Then, intermittently, sometime between 60,000 and 80,000 years ago, tiny groups of them began to enter the north-west of the Indian subcontinent. It seems likely that initially they came by way of the coast. ... it is virtually certain that there were <i>Homo sapiens</i> in the subcontinent 55,000 years ago, even though the earliest fossils that have been found of them date to only about 30,000 years before the present."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Fisher2018p23-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Fisher2018p23_41-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Fisher2018p23_41-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA23">23</a>, "Scholars estimate that the first successful expansion of the <i>Homo sapiens</i> range beyond Africa and across the Arabian Peninsula occurred from as early as 80,000 years ago to as late as 40,000 years ago, although there may have been prior unsuccessful emigrations. Some of their descendants extended the human range ever further in each generation, spreading into each habitable land they encountered. One human channel was along the warm and productive coastal lands of the Persian Gulf and northern Indian Ocean. Eventually, various bands entered India between 75,000 years ago and 35,000 years ago."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-28a_42-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA28">28</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Combined-2-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-2_43-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) <a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4">4–5</a>;<br>(b) <a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA23">33</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lowe2015-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lowe2015_44-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFLowe2015" class="citation book cs1">Lowe, John J. (2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=L07CBwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA2"><i>Participles in Rigvedic Sanskrit: The syntax and semantics of adjectival verb forms</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp.&nbsp;1–2. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100505-3"><bdi>978-0-19-100505-3</bdi></a>. <q>(The Rigveda) consists of 1,028 hymns (suktas), highly crafted poetic compositions originally intended for recital during rituals and for the invocation of and communication with the Indo-Aryan gods. Modern scholarly opinion largely agrees that these hymns were composed between around 1500&nbsp;BCE and 1200&nbsp;BCE, during the eastward migration of the Indo-Aryan tribes from the mountains of what is today northern Afghanistan across the Punjab into north India.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Participles+in+Rigvedic+Sanskrit%3A+The+syntax+and+semantics+of+adjectival+verb+forms&amp;rft.pages=1-2&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100505-3&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DL07CBwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Combined-4-Rigveda-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-4-Rigveda_45-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFWitzel2008" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Michael_Witzel" title="Michael Witzel">Witzel, Michael</a> (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=SKBxa-MNqA8C&amp;pg=PA68">"Vedas and Upanisads"</a>. In Gavin Flood (ed.). <i>The Blackwell Companion to Hinduism</i>. <a href="/wiki/John_Wiley_%26_Sons" class="mw-redirect" title="John Wiley &amp; Sons">John Wiley &amp; Sons</a>. pp.&nbsp;68–70. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-470-99868-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-470-99868-7"><bdi>978-0-470-99868-7</bdi></a>. <q>It is known from internal evidence that the Vedic texts were orally composed in northern India, at first in the Greater Punjab and later on also in more eastern areas, including northern Bihar, between ca. 1500 BCE and ca. 500–400 BCE. The oldest text, the Rgveda, must have been more or less contemporary with the Mitanni texts of northern Syria/Iraq (1450–1350 BCE); ... The Vedic texts were orally composed and transmitted, without the use of script, in an unbroken line of transmission from teacher to student that was formalised early on.  This ensured an impeccable textual transmission superior to the classical texts of other cultures; it is in fact something of a <i>tape-recording</i> of ca. 1500–500 BCE. Not just the actual words, but even the long-lost musical (tonal) accent (as in old Greek or in Japanese) has been preserved up to the present. (pp. 68–69) ... The RV text was composed before the introduction and massive use of iron, that is before ca. 1200–1000 BCE. (p. 70)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Vedas+and+Upanisads&amp;rft.btitle=The+Blackwell+Companion+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=68-70&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-470-99868-7&amp;rft.aulast=Witzel&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DSKBxa-MNqA8C%26pg%3DPA68&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span><br>(b) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFDoniger2014" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Wendy_Doniger" title="Wendy Doniger">Doniger, Wendy</a> (2014), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fUnaAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PR18"><i>On Hinduism</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, pp.&nbsp;xviii, 10, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-936009-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-936009-3"><bdi>978-0-19-936009-3</bdi></a>, <q>A Chronology of Hinduism: ca. 1500–1000 BCE Rig Veda; ca. 1200–900 BCE Yajur Veda, Sama Veda and Atharva Veda (p. xviii); Hindu texts began with the <i>Rig Veda</i> ('Knowledge of Verses'), composed in northwest India around 1500 BCE (p. 10)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=On+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=xviii%2C+10&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-936009-3&amp;rft.aulast=Doniger&amp;rft.aufirst=Wendy&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DfUnaAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPR18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span><br>(c) <a href="#CITEREFLudden2014">Ludden 2014</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pBq9DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA19">19</a>, "In Punjab, a dry region with grasslands watered by five rivers (hence 'panch' and 'ab') draining the western Himalayas, one prehistoric culture left no material remains, but some of its ritual texts were preserved orally over the millennia. The culture is called Aryan, and evidence in its texts indicates that it spread slowly south-east, following the course of the Yamuna and Ganga Rivers. Its elite called itself Arya (pure) and distinguished themselves sharply from others. Aryans led kin groups organized as nomadic horse-herding tribes. Their ritual texts are called Vedas, composed in Sanskrit. <a href="/wiki/Vedic_Sanskrit" title="Vedic Sanskrit">Vedic Sanskrit</a> is recorded only in hymns that were part of Vedic rituals to Aryan gods. To be Aryan apparently meant to belong to the elite among pastoral tribes. Texts that record Aryan culture are not precisely datable, but they seem to begin around 1200 BCE with four collections of Vedic hymns (Rg, Sama, Yajur, and Artharva)."
<br>(d) <a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA14">14–15</a>, "Although the collapse of the Indus valley civilization is no longer believed to have been due to an 'Aryan invasion' it is widely thought that, at roughly the same time, or perhaps a few centuries later, new Indo-Aryan-speaking people and influences began to enter the subcontinent from the north-west. Detailed evidence is lacking. Nevertheless, a predecessor of the language that would eventually be called Sanskrit was probably introduced into the north-west sometime between 3,900 and 3,000 years ago. This language was related to one then spoken in eastern Iran; and both of these languages belonged to the Indo-European language family. ... It seems likely that various small-scale migrations were involved in the gradual introduction of the predecessor language and associated cultural characteristics. However, there may not have been a tight relationship between movements of people on the one hand, and changes in language and culture on the other. Moreover, the process whereby a dynamic new force gradually arose—a people with a distinct ideology who eventually seem to have referred to themselves as 'Arya'—was certainly two-way. That is, it involved a blending of new features which came from outside with other features—probably including some surviving Harappan influences—that were already present. Anyhow, it would be quite a few centuries before Sanskrit was written down. And the hymns and stories of the Arya people—especially the Vedas and the later Mahabharata and Ramayana epics—are poor guides as to historical events. Of course, the emerging Arya were to have a huge impact on the history of the subcontinent. Nevertheless, little is known about their early presence."; <br> (e) <a href="#CITEREFRobb2011">Robb 2011</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=GQ-2VH1LO_EC&amp;pg=PA46">46–</a>, "The expansion of Aryan culture is supposed to have begun around 1500 BCE. It should not be thought that this Aryan emergence (though it implies some migration) necessarily meant either a sudden invasion of new peoples, or a complete break with earlier traditions. It comprises a set of cultural ideas and practices, upheld by a Sanskrit-speaking elite, or Aryans. The features of this society are recorded in the Vedas."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Combined-3-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-3_46-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFJamisonBrereton2020" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Stephanie_W._Jamison" title="Stephanie W. Jamison">Jamison, Stephanie</a>; Brereton, Joel (2020), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1LTRDwAAQBAJ"><i>The Rigveda</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, pp.&nbsp;2, 4, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-063339-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-063339-4"><bdi>978-0-19-063339-4</bdi></a>, <q>The RgVeda is one of the four Vedas, which together constitute the oldest texts in Sanskrit and the earliest evidence for what will become Hinduism. (p. 2)  Although Vedic religion is very different in many regards from what is known as Classical Hinduism, the seeds are there. Gods like Visnu and Siva (under the name Rudra), who will become so dominant later, are already present in the Rgveda, though in roles both lesser than and different from those they will later play, and the principal Rgvedic gods like Indra remain in later Hinduism, though in diminished capacity (p. 4).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Rigveda&amp;rft.pages=2%2C+4&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-063339-4&amp;rft.aulast=Jamison&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.au=Brereton%2C+Joel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1LTRDwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>;<br>(b) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFFlood2020" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Flood, Gavin</a> (2020), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4yT3DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA4">"Introduction"</a>, in Gavin Flood (ed.), <i>The Oxford History of Hinduism: Hindu Practice: Hindu Practice</i>, <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>, pp.&nbsp;4–, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-105322-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-105322-1"><bdi>978-0-19-105322-1</bdi></a>, <q>I take the term 'Hinduism to meaningfully denote a range and history of practice characterised by a number of features, particularly reference to Vedic textual and sacrificial origins, belonging to endogamous social units (jati/varna), participating in practices that involve making an offering to a deity and receiving a blessing (puja), and a first-level cultural polytheism (although many Hindus adhere to a second-level monotheism in which many gods are regarded as emanations or manifestations of the one, supreme being).</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+History+of+Hinduism%3A+Hindu+Practice%3A+Hindu+Practice&amp;rft.pages=4-&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2020&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-105322-1&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4yT3DwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span>;<br>(c) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFMichaels2017" class="citation book cs1"><a href="/wiki/Axel_Michaels" title="Axel Michaels">Michaels, Axel</a> (2017). Patrick Olivelle, Donald R. Davis (ed.). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QAJCDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA86"><i>The Oxford History of Hinduism: Hindu Law: A New History of Dharmaśāstra</i></a>. Oxford: <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp.&nbsp;86–97. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100709-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-100709-5"><bdi>978-0-19-100709-5</bdi></a>. <q>Almost all traditional Hindu families observe until today at least three <i>samskaras</i> (initiation, marriage, and death ritual).  Most other rituals have lost their popularity, are combined with other rites of passage, or are drastically shortened.  Although <i>samskaras</i> vary from region to region, from class (<i>varna</i>) to class, and from caste to caste, their core elements remain the same owing to the common source, the Veda, and a common priestly tradition preserved by the <i>Brahmin</i> priests. (p 86)</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Oxford+History+of+Hinduism%3A+Hindu+Law%3A+A+New+History+of+Dharma%C5%9B%C4%81stra&amp;rft.place=Oxford&amp;rft.pages=86-97&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-100709-5&amp;rft.aulast=Michaels&amp;rft.aufirst=Axel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQAJCDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA86&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span><br>(d) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFFlood1996" class="citation book cs1">Flood, Gavin D. (1996). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KpIWhKnYmF0C&amp;pg=PA35"><i>An Introduction to Hinduism</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Cambridge_University_Press" title="Cambridge University Press">Cambridge University Press</a>. p.&nbsp;35. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-43878-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-43878-0"><bdi>978-0-521-43878-0</bdi></a>. <q>It is this Sansrit, vedic, tradition which has maintained a continuity into modern times and which has provided the most important resource and inspiration for Hindu traditions and individuals.  The Veda is the foundation for most later developments in what is known as Hinduism.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introduction+to+Hinduism&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-43878-0&amp;rft.aulast=Flood&amp;rft.aufirst=Gavin+D.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DKpIWhKnYmF0C%26pg%3DPA35&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Combined-4-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Combined-4_47-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA16">16</a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA25">25</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-16a-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-16a_48-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA16">16</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-EmbreeHay1988-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-EmbreeHay1988_67-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFEmbreeHayBary1988" class="citation cs2">Embree, Ainslie Thomas; Hay, Stephen N.; Bary, William Theodore De (1988), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XoMRuiSpBp4C&amp;pg=PA85">"Nationalism Takes Root: The Moderates"</a>, <i>Sources of Indian Tradition: Modern India and Pakistan</i>, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University_Press" title="Columbia University Press">Columbia University Press</a>, p.&nbsp;85, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-06414-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-06414-9"><bdi>978-0-231-06414-9</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Nationalism+Takes+Root%3A+The+Moderates&amp;rft.btitle=Sources+of+Indian+Tradition%3A+Modern+India+and+Pakistan&amp;rft.pages=85&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1988&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-06414-9&amp;rft.aulast=Embree&amp;rft.aufirst=Ainslie+Thomas&amp;rft.au=Hay%2C+Stephen+N.&amp;rft.au=Bary%2C+William+Theodore+De&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DXoMRuiSpBp4C%26pg%3DPA85&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Marshall2001-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Marshall2001_68-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFMarshall2001" class="citation cs2">Marshall, P. J. (2001), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=S2EXN8JTwAEC&amp;pg=PAPA179"><i>The Cambridge Illustrated History of the British Empire</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, p.&nbsp;179, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00254-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-00254-7"><bdi>978-0-521-00254-7</bdi></a>, <q>The first modern nationalist movement to arise in the non-European empire, and one that became an inspiration for many others, was the Indian Congress.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cambridge+Illustrated+History+of+the+British+Empire&amp;rft.pages=179&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-00254-7&amp;rft.aulast=Marshall&amp;rft.aufirst=P.+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DS2EXN8JTwAEC%26pg%3DPAPA179&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Chiriyankandath2016-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Chiriyankandath2016_69-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFChiriyankandath2016" class="citation cs2">Chiriyankandath, James (2016), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=c4n7CwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PAPA2"><i>Parties and Political Change in South Asia</i></a>, Routledge, p.&nbsp;2, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-58620-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-58620-3"><bdi>978-1-317-58620-3</bdi></a>, <q>South Asian parties include several of the oldest in the post-colonial world, foremost among them the 129-year-old Indian National Congress that led India to independence in 1947</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Parties+and+Political+Change+in+South+Asia&amp;rft.pages=2&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-58620-3&amp;rft.aulast=Chiriyankandath&amp;rft.aufirst=James&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dc4n7CwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPAPA2&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-fisher-partition-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-fisher-partition_70-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;173–174: "The partition of South Asia that produced India and West and East Pakistan resulted from years of bitter negotiations and recriminations ... The departing British also decreed that the hundreds of princes, who ruled one-third of the subcontinent and a quarter of its population, became legally independent, their status to be settled later. Geographical location, personal and popular sentiment, and substantial pressure and incentives from the new governments led almost all princes eventually to merge their domains into either Pakistan or India.  ...  Each new government asserted its exclusive sovereignty within its borders, realigning all territories, animals, plants, minerals, and all other natural and human-made resources as either Pakistani or Indian property, to be used for its national development... Simultaneously, the central civil and military services and judiciary split roughly along religious 'communal' lines, even as they divided movable government assets according to a negotiated formula: 22.7 percent for Pakistan and 77.3 percent for India."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-chatterji-partition-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-chatterji-partition_71-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFChatterjiWashbrook2013" class="citation cs2">Chatterji, Joya; Washbrook, David (2013), "Introduction: Concepts and Questions", in Chatterji, Joya; Washbrook, David (eds.), <i>Routledge Handbook of the South Asian Diaspora</i>, London and New York: Routledge, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-48010-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-48010-9"><bdi>978-0-415-48010-9</bdi></a>, <q><a href="/wiki/Joya_Chatterji" title="Joya Chatterji">Joya Chatterji</a>  describes how the partition of the British Indian empire into the new nation states of India and Pakistan produced new diaspora on a vast, and hitherto unprecedented, scale, but hints that the sheer magnitude of refugee movements in South Asia after 1947 must be understood in the context of pre-existing migratory flows within the partitioned regions (see also Chatterji 2013). She also demonstrates that the new national states of India and Pakistan were quickly drawn into trying to stem this migration. As they put into place laws designed to restrict the return of partition emigrants, this produced new dilemmas for both new nations in their treatment of 'overseas Indians'; and many of them lost their right to return to their places of origin in the subcontinent, and also their claims to full citizenship in host countries.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction%3A+Concepts+and+Questions&amp;rft.btitle=Routledge+Handbook+of+the+South+Asian+Diaspora&amp;rft.place=London+and+New+York&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-48010-9&amp;rft.aulast=Chatterji&amp;rft.aufirst=Joya&amp;rft.au=Washbrook%2C+David&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-talbot-sing-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-talbot-sing_72-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFTalbotSingh2009" class="citation cs2">Talbot, Ian; Singh, Gurharpal (2009), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=utKmPQAACAAJ"><i>The Partition of India</i></a>, Cambridge University Press, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85661-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85661-4"><bdi>978-0-521-85661-4</bdi></a>, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20161213073754/https://books.google.com/books?id=utKmPQAACAAJ">archived</a> from the original on 13 December 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">15 November</span> 2015</span>, <q>When the British divided and quit India in August 1947, they not only partitioned the subcontinent with the emergence of the two nations of India and Pakistan but also the provinces of Punjab and Bengal. ... Indeed for many the Indian subcontinent's division in August 1947 is seen as a unique event which defies comparative historical and conceptual analysis</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Partition+of+India&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85661-4&amp;rft.aulast=Talbot&amp;rft.aufirst=Ian&amp;rft.au=Singh%2C+Gurharpal&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DutKmPQAACAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-khan-great-partition-73"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-khan-great-partition_73-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFKhan2017" class="citation cs2"><a href="/wiki/Yasmin_Khan" title="Yasmin Khan">Khan, Yasmin</a> (2017) [2007], <i>The Great Partition: The Making of India and Pakistan</i> (2nd&nbsp;ed.), New Haven and London: Yale University Press, p.&nbsp;1, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-300-23032-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-300-23032-1"><bdi>978-0-300-23032-1</bdi></a>, <q>South Asians learned that the British Indian empire would be partitioned on 3 June 1947.  They heard about it on the radio, from relations and friends, by reading newspapers and, later, through government pamphlets.  Among a population of almost four hundred million, where the vast majority live in the countryside, ploughing the land as landless peasants or sharecroppers, it is hardly surprising that many thousands, perhaps hundreds of thousands, did not hear the news for many weeks afterwards. For some, the butchery and forced relocation of the summer months of 1947 may have been the first that they knew about the creation of the two new states rising from the fragmentary and terminally weakened British empire in India</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Great+Partition%3A+The+Making+of+India+and+Pakistan&amp;rft.place=New+Haven+and+London&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Yale+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-300-23032-1&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-74"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-74" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) <a href="#CITEREFCopland2001">Copland 2001</a>, pp.&nbsp;71–78;<br>(b) <a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2006">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2006</a>, p.&nbsp;222.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-219-75"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-219_75-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA219">219</a>, 262</span>

<li id="cite_note-Fisher2018-8-76"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Fisher2018-8_76-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kZVuDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA8">8</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265_77-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2012">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2012</a>, pp.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mjIfqyY7jlsC&amp;pg=PA265">265–266</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-266-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MetcalfMetcalf2012-266_78-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2012">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2012</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=mjIfqyY7jlsC&amp;pg=PA266">266</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Dyson2018-216-a-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Dyson2018-216-a_79-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDyson2018">Dyson 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=3TRtDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA216">216</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-kashmir-disputes-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-kashmir-disputes_80-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(a) <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation cs2"><span class="cs1-lock-subscription" title="Paid subscription required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Kashmir-region-Indian-subcontinent">"Kashmir, region Indian subcontinent"</a></span>, <i><a subject of dispute between India and Pakistan since the partition of the Indian subcontinent in 1947.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Kashmir%2C+region+Indian+subcontinent&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopaedia+Britannica&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FKashmir-region-Indian-subcontinent&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" The region has been the subject of a bitter dispute between India and Pakistan since they became independent in 1947</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Kashmir&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Americana%3A+Jefferson+to+Latin&amp;rft.pages=328&amp;rft.pub=Scholastic+Library+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7172-0139-6&amp;rft.aulast=Bosworth&amp;rft.aufirst=C.+E&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dl_cWAQAAMAAJ%26pg%3DPA328&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-NarayanJohn2018-lead-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NarayanJohn2018-lead_81-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFNarayanJohnRamadas2018" class="citation journal cs1">Narayan, Jitendra; John, Denny; Ramadas, Nirupama (2018). "Malnutrition in India: status and government initiatives". <i><a href="/wiki/Journal_of_Public_Health_Policy" title="Journal of Public Health Policy">Journal of Public Health Policy</a></i>. <b>40</b> (1): 126–141. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1057%2Fs41271-018-0149-5">10.1057/s41271-018-0149-5</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/issn/0197-5897">0197-5897</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30353132">30353132</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:53032234">53032234</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Public+Health+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Malnutrition+in+India%3A+status+and+government+initiatives&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=126-141&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.issn=0197-5897&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A53032234%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F30353132&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1057%2Fs41271-018-0149-5&amp;rft.aulast=Narayan&amp;rft.aufirst=Jitendra&amp;rft.au=John%2C+Denny&amp;rft.au=Ramadas%2C+Nirupama&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-BalakrishnanDey2019-lead-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-BalakrishnanDey2019-lead_82-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFBalakrishnanDey2019" class="citation journal cs1">Balakrishnan, Kalpana; Dey, Sagnik; et&nbsp;al. (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6358127">"The impact of air pollution on deaths, disease burden, and life expectancy across the states of India: the Global Burden of Disease Study 2017"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet_Planetary_Health" class="mw-redirect" title="The Lancet Planetary Health">The Lancet Planetary Health</a></i>. <b>3</b> (1): e26–e39. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1016%2FS2542-5196%2818%2930261-4">10.1016/S2542-5196(18)30261-4</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldcat.org/issn/2542-5196">2542-5196</a>. <a href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a>&nbsp;<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6358127">6358127</a></span>. <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30528905">30528905</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Lancet+Planetary+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+air+pollution+on+deaths%2C+disease+burden%2C+and+life+expectancy+across+the+states+of+India%3A+the+Global+Burden+of+Disease+Study+2017&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=e26-e39&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6358127%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft.issn=2542-5196&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F30528905&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1016%2FS2542-5196%2818%2930261-4&amp;rft.aulast=Balakrishnan&amp;rft.aufirst=Kalpana&amp;rft.au=Dey%2C+Sagnik&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6358127&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-IUCN-India-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-IUCN-India_83-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-IUCN-India_83-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20201101033802/https://www.iucn.org/asia/countries/india"><i>India</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature" title="International Union for Conservation of Nature">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a> (IUCN), 2019, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.iucn.org/asia/countries/india">the original</a> on 1 November 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 May</span> 2019</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=India&amp;rft.pub=International+Union+for+Conservation+of+Nature+%28IUCN%29&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iucn.org%2Fasia%2Fcountries%2Findia&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140909230437/https://lawmin.nic.in/coi/coiason29july08.pdf"><i>The Constitution of India</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>, <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Law_and_Justice_(India)" title="Ministry of Law and Justice (India)">Ministry of Law and Justice</a>, 1 December 2007, archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://lawmin.nic.in/coi/coiason29july08.pdf">the original</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> on 9 September 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 March</span> 2012</span>, <q>Article 1(1): India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Constitution+of+India&amp;rft.pub=Ministry+of+Law+and+Justice&amp;rft.date=2007-12-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Flawmin.nic.in%2Fcoi%2Fcoiason29july08.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Jha2014-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jha2014_91-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFJha2014" class="citation cs2">Jha, Dwijendra Narayan (2014), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=dqDgBQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA11"><i>Rethinking Hindu Identity</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a>, p.&nbsp;11, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-49034-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-49034-0"><bdi>978-1-317-49034-0</bdi></a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Rethinking+Hindu+Identity&amp;rft.pages=11&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-49034-0&amp;rft.aulast=Jha&amp;rft.aufirst=Dwijendra+Narayan&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DdqDgBQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA11&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddYM4DwAAQBAJpgPA253_253]-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddYM4DwAAQBAJpgPA253_253]_92-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSingh2017">Singh 2017</a>, p.&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=dYM4DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA253">253</a>.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003_93-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003_93-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBarrow2003">Barrow 2003</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFPaturiPatterson2016" class="citation book cs1">Paturi, Joseph; Patterson, Roger (2016). "Hinduism (with Hare Krishna)". In Hodge, Bodie; Patterson, Roger (eds.). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=oCo5DAAAQBAJ"><i>World Religions &amp; Cults Volume 2: Moralistic, Mythical and Mysticism Religions</i></a>. United States: New Leaf Publishing Group. pp.&nbsp;59–60. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-89051-922-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-89051-922-6"><bdi>978-0-89051-922-6</bdi></a>. <q>The actual term Hindu first occurs as a Persian geographical term for the people who lived beyond the Indus River. The term Hindu originated as a geographical term and did not refer to a religion. Later, Hindu was taken by European languages from the Arabic term al-Hind, which referred to the people who lived across the Indus River. This Arabic term was itself taken from the Persian term Hindū, which refers to all Indians. By the 13th century, Hindustan emerged as a popular alternative name for India, meaning the "land of Hindus."<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span></q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Hinduism+%28with+Hare+Krishna%29&amp;rft.btitle=World+Religions+%26+Cults+Volume+2%3A+Moralistic%2C+Mythical+and+Mysticism+Religions&amp;rft.place=United+States&amp;rft.pages=59-60&amp;rft.pub=New+Leaf+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-89051-922-6&amp;rft.aulast=Paturi&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rft.au=Patterson%2C+Roger&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DoCo5DAAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-95" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite class="citation cs2"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/266465/Hindustan">"Hindustan"</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 July</span> 2011</span></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Hindustan&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2FEBchecked%2Ftopic%2F266465%2FHindustan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lowe2017-epic-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lowe2017-epic_96-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631"><cite id="CITEREFLowe2017" class="citation book cs1">Lowe, John J. (2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nSgmDwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA58"><i>Transitive Nouns and Adjectives: Evidence from Early Indo-Aryan</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. p.&nbsp;58. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879357-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-879357-1"><bdi>978-0-19-879357-1</bdi></a>. <q>The term 'Epic Sanskrit' refers to the language of the two great Sanskrit epics, the Mahābhārata and the Rāmāyaṇa. ...  It is likely, therefore, that the epic-like elements found in Vedic sources and the two epics that we have are not directly related, but that both drew on the same source, an oral tradition of storytelling that existed before, throughout, and after the Vedic period.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Transitive+Nouns+and+Adjectives%3A+Evidence+from+Early+Indo-Aryan&amp;rft.pages=58&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-879357-1&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=John+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DnSgmDwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA58&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIndia" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105_97-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104–105_97-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFConinghamYoung2015">Coningham &amp; Young 2015</a>, pp.&nbsp;104–105.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_184-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247–248_184-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2006">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2006</a>, pp.&nbsp;247–248.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304_185-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMetcalfMetcalf2006">Metcalf &amp; Metcalf 2006</a>, p.&nbsp;304.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-0"><span class="cite-accessibility-label">Jump up to: </span><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005_186-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFAliAitchison2005">Ali &amp; Aitchison 2005</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20237-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20237_187-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDikshitSchwartzberg2023">Dikshit &amp; Schwartzberg 2023</a>, p.&nbsp;7.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000_188-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPrakash_et_al.2000">Prakash et al. 2000</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-aravalli-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-aravalli_189-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKaul1970">Kaul 1970</a>, p.&nbsp;160, "&nbsp;The Aravalli range boldy defines the eastern limit of the arid and semi-arid zone. Probably the more humid conditions that prevail near the Aravallis prevented the extension of aridity towards the east and the Ganges Valley. It is noteworthy that, wherever there are gaps in this range, sand has advanced to the east of it."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-prasad-aravalli-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-prasad-aravalli_190-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPrasad1974">Prasad 1974</a>, p.&nbsp;372, "&nbsp;The topography of the Indian Desert is dominated by the Aravalli Ranges on its eastern border, which consist largely of tightly folded and highly metamorphosed Archaean rocks."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-fisher-aravalli-191"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-fisher-aravalli_191-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFisher2018">Fisher 2018</a>, p.&nbsp;83, "&nbsp;East of the lower Indus lay the inhospitable Rann of Kutch and Thar Desert. East of the upper Indus lay the more promising but narrow corridor between the Himalayan foothills on the north and the Thar Desert and Aravalli Mountains on the south. At the strategic choke point, just before reaching the fertile, well-watered Gangetic plain, sat Delhi. On this site, where life giving streams running off the most northern spur of the rocky Aravalli ridge flowed into the Jumna river, and where the war-horse and war-elephant trade intersected, a series of dynasties built fortified capitals."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003257-192"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003257_192-0" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003">Mcgrail et al. 2003</a>, p.&nbsp;257.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-211"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-211" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link
